This statement is incorrect. Logistics management is not the sole responsibility of the marketing function. It is a cross-functional activity that involves various departments within an organization, such as supply chain, operations, procurement, distribution, and more. Effective logistics management requires collaboration among different departments to ensure smooth and efficient movement of goods throughout the supply chain.

Question 24
Which one of the advertising planning strategies is suitable for cars and appliances?
  • A.Informative strategy
  • B.Affective strategy
  • C.Habitual strategy
  • D.Satisfaction strategy
Correct Answer: Informative strategy

The correct answer is option A - Informative strategy.

 

An informative advertising strategy is suitable for products like cars and appliances. This strategy focuses on providing consumers with detailed information about the features, benefits, and specifications of the products. Cars and appliances are often considered high-involvement purchases where consumers want to make well-informed decisions based on the features and performance of the products.

 

Using an informative strategy helps potential buyers understand the technical details, performance capabilities, energy efficiency, safety features, and other relevant information about the product. This approach aims to educate consumers and provide them with the necessary information to make a rational purchase decision.

 

In contrast, affective strategies might focus more on creating emotional connections or eliciting certain feelings related to the product, which may be more appropriate for products that are associated with lifestyle or emotional benefits.

Question 25
Which of the following are skills and capabilities related competencies?a) Analysisb) Intellectual curiosityc) Organizationd) Problem solvinge) Ownership of assignmentsChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.a, c and d only
  • B.a, b and c only
  • C.b, c and d only
  • D.a, d and e only
Correct Answer: a, c and d only

Option A is the correct answer.

 

The skills and capabilities related competencies mentioned in the options are:

a) Analysis

c) Organization

d) Problem solving

Question 26
Experimental treatment in research design signifies which of the following?
  • A.Selection of dependent variable
  • B.Manipulating independent variable
  • C.Selection of independent variable
  • D.Manipulating dependent variable
Correct Answer: Manipulating independent variable

Option B is the correct answer.

 

The experimental treatment is the manipulation applied to the independent variable to observe its effect on the dependent variable. It involves changing a variable to observe the impact on another variable and is a fundamental aspect of experimental research.

Question 27
Which of the following one considered as supply factors affecting the flow of Foreign Direct Investment (FDI)?a) Customer Accessb) Economic Prioritiesc) Resource Availabilityd) Avoidance of Trade Barriere) LogisticsChoose the most appropriate answer from the option given below:
  • A.a and b only
  • B.b and d only
  • C.c and e only
  • D.a and e only
Correct Answer: c and e only

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) flows are influenced by a variety of factors, which can be categorized into supply-side and demand-side factors. Supply-side factors refer to conditions and characteristics of the investing country, while demand-side factors relate to conditions in the host country where the investment is made.

 

Hence, only c and e are factors.

Question 28
Match list I with II list.List I (Purpose)A. Study all aspects of Electronic Fund Transfer (EFT)B. Working group on NBFCsC. Suggest alternate methods of LendingD. Expert group on Foreign exchange marketsList II (Committee)I. RashidJilaniCommittee (1992)II.SodhaniCommittee (1994)III.MalegamCommittee (1995)IV.ShereCommittee (1995)Choose the correct answer from the question given below:
  • A.A-III, B-I, C-II, D-IV
  • B.A-II, B-I, C-III, D-IV
  • C.A-I, B-III, C-II, D-IV
  • D.A-IV, B-III, C-I, D-II
Correct Answer: A-IV, B-III, C-I, D-II

Option D is the correct answer.

 

Rashid Jilani Committee (1992)

Suggest alternate methods of lending.

 

This committee was formed to examine and recommend alternate methods of lending by banks, especially looking at ways to improve the lending process.

 

Sodhani Committee (1994)

Expert group on Foreign exchange markets.

 

The committee was constituted to review and suggest improvements in the functioning of the foreign exchange markets in India.

 

Malegam Committee (1995)

Working group on Non-Banking Financial Companies (NBFCs).

 

This committee was formed to study and make recommendations on issues related to Non-Banking Financial Companies, including regulatory and operational aspects.

 

Shere Committee (1995)

Study all aspects of Electronic Fund Transfer (EFT).

 

The committee was tasked with studying various aspects of Electronic Fund Transfer (EFT) and providing recommendations to enhance the efficiency and security of electronic transactions.

Question 29
If the application for information is rejected under the Right to Information Act 2005, the CPIO/SPIO is obligated which of the following to furnish the person seeking the information?(a) Power and functions of information commission(b) Reasons for such rejection(c) Obligation of public authorities(d) The particulars of the appellant authority(e) The period within which an appeal against such rejection may be preferredChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.b and c only
  • B.b, c and d only
  • C.a, c and e only
  • D.b, d and e only
Correct Answer: b, d and e only

When such application is rejected under the Right to Information Act, 2005, the Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer, as the case may be, shall communicate to the person making the request:

(i) the reasons for such rejection;

(ii) the period within which an appeal against such rejection may be preferred; and

(iii) the particulars of the appellate authority.

 

Thus, option D is correct.

Question 30
X was appointed on 1 July 2022 as a lecturer in a University. He was continued on 30 April 2023. What would be the duration of the previous year for the assessment year 2023-24 for computation of income under the head Salary?
  • A.1 July 2022 to 30 April 2023
  • B.1 April 2022 to 31 March 2023
  • C.1 April 2022 to 30 April 2023
  • D.1 July 2022 to 31 March 2023
Correct Answer: 1 July 2022 to 31 March 2023

The period from July 1, 2022 to March 31, 2023 is the previous year for the assessment year 2023-24 in the given case, as per Income Tax Act, 1961.

Question 31
In case of presence of outliers in a data set, which of the following can better measure the central tendency?a) Modeb) Trimmed Meanc) Arithmetic Meand) Mediane) Harmonic MeanChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a and b only
  • B.b and c only
  • C.c and e only
  • D.b and d only
Correct Answer: b and d only

In the presence of outliers, the following measures of central tendency are often more robust:

 

Trimmed Mean: The trimmed mean involves removing a certain percentage of data points from both ends (high and low) of the dataset and then calculating the mean of the remaining values. This helps mitigate the impact of outliers.

 

Median: The median is less sensitive to extreme values and is a good measure of central tendency when outliers are present. It is the middle value of a dataset when it is ordered.

Question 32
The assumptions of Purchasing Power Parity Theory includes:a) No costs for converting one currency to anotherb) No restrictions on the movement of capital between countriesc) No restrictions on the movement of commodities between countriesd) No transaction costs for buying and selling financial securitye) No transportation costs for transporting a commodity from one country to another.Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.a, b and c only
  • B.b, d and c only
  • C.e, a and c only
  • D.d, a and e only
Correct Answer: e, a and c only

The assumptions of Purchasing Power Parity Theory includes:

 

a) No costs for converting one currency to another: This assumption ensures that there are no transaction costs or fees associated with currency conversion.

 

c) No restrictions on the movement of commodities between countries: This assumption means that goods and services can move freely between countries, without any restrictions or barriers.

 

e) No transportation costs for transporting a commodity from one country to another: This assumption implies that there are no additional costs related to transporting goods from one country to another.

 

Options b) and d) are not included because they involve assumptions related to capital and financial securities, which are not specifically part of the Purchasing Power Parity (PPP) theory.

Question 33
Arrange the following steps in a logical sequence in resource todishonoringa negotiable instrument:(a) Noting(b) Compensation(c) Protesting(d) Notice ofdishonor(e) PenaltiesChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.d, a, c, b, e
  • B.c, d, a, b, e
  • C.c, d, e, b, a
  • D.a, c, d, b, e
Correct Answer: d, a, c, b, e

Under the provisions of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881, following are the relevant chapters:

 

Chapter VIII - Notice of Dishonour

Chapter IX – Noting and Protest

Chapter XII – Compensation

Chapter XVII - Penalties in case of dishonour of certain cheques for insufficiency of funds in the accounts

 

According to Section 93, When a promissory note, bill of exchange or cheque is dishonoured by non-acceptance or non-payment, the holder thereof, or some party thereto who remains liable thereon, must give notice that the instrument has been so dishonoured to all other parties whom the holder seeks to make severally liable thereon, and to some one of several parties whom he seeks to make jointly liable thereon.

 

Noting: According to section 99, when a promissory note or bill of exchange has been dishonoured by non-acceptance, or non-payment the holder may cause such dishonour to be noted by a notary public upon the instrument, or on a paper attached thereto, or partly upon each. Such note must be made within a reasonable time after dishonour, and must specify the date of dishonour, the reason for the dishonour or if the instrument has not been expressly dishonoured, the reason why the holder treats it as dishonour and the notary’s charges.

 

Protest: According to Section 100, when a promissory note or bill of exchange has been dishonoured by non-acceptance or non-payment, the holder may within a reasonable time, cause such dishonour to be noted and certified by a notary public. Such certificate is called a protest.

 

Thus, correct answer is option A.

Question 34
Arrange the following goods and services in the increasing order of the underlying income elasticity of demand.a) Normal consumption goodsb) Necessitiesc) Luxuriesd) Inferior goodse) ServicesChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.d, b, a, e, c
  • B.d, c, b, a, e
  • C.c, e, b, a, d
  • D.b, a, d, c, e
Correct Answer: d, b, a, e, c

Option A is the correct answer.

 

Income elasticity of demand measures how the quantity demanded of a good or service responds to changes in income. Here's how these categories generally align in terms of income elasticity:

 

Inferior goods: Negative income elasticity (as income increases, demand decreases).

 

Necessities: Low positive income elasticity (demand increases with income, but not at a high rate).

 

Normal consumption goods: Moderate positive income elasticity (demand increases with income at a moderate rate).

 

Luxuries: High positive income elasticity (demand increases significantly with income).

 

Services: The income elasticity for services can vary but is generally positive, and the demand may increase with income.

Question 35
Match the list I and IIList-I (A.T Kearney Globalization Index)A. Economic IntegrationB. Personal IntegrationC. Technological IntegrationD. Political IntegrationList-II (Variables)I. International Tourism and TravelII. Internet UsersIII. Foreign Direct InvestmentIV. Ratification and multilateral treatiesChoose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.A-IV, B-III, C-II, D-I
  • B.A-III, B-I, C-II, D-IV
  • C.A-III, B-II, C-I, D-IV
  • D.A-IV, B-I, C-II, D-III
Correct Answer: A-III, B-I, C-II, D-IV

Option B is the correct answer.

 

The A.T. Kearney Globalization Index is an annual report published by the global management consulting firm A.T. Kearney. The index assesses the degree of globalization in different countries based on various factors. The Index measures globalization based on 4 pillars: Economic Integration, Personal Integration, Technological Integration, and Political Integration. Here's the correct match between

 

A. Economic Integration: III. Foreign Direct Investment

B. Personal Integration: I. International Tourism and Travel

C. Technological Integration: II. Internet Users

D. Political Integration: IV. Ratification and multilateral treaties

Question 36
Match list I and list IIList I (Accounting Concept)A. Going Concern ConceptB. ConsistencyC. Cost ConceptD. MaterialityList II (Purpose Applicability)I. The same accounting method used by a firm from one period to anotherII. Relate to the relative size or importance of an item or event.III. An inappropriate assumption for firm undergoing bankruptcyIV. The normal basis used to account for assetsChoose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.A-II, B-III, C-IV, D-I
  • B.A-I, B-II, C-III, D-IV
  • C.A-I, B-II, C-IV, D-III
  • D.A-III, B-I, C-IV, D-II
Correct Answer: A-III, B-I, C-IV, D-II

The correct match is as follows.

LIST I - LIST II

(Accounting Concept) - (Purpose /Applicability)

A. Going Concern Concept - An inappropriate assumption for firm undergoing bankruptcy

B. Consistency - The same accounting method used by a firm from one period to another

C. Cost Concept - The normal basis used to account for assets

D. Materiality - Relate to the relative size or importance of an item or event

Question 37
Match the list Iwithlist IIList I (Schedules under the Companies Act, 2013)A. Schedule IB. Schedule IIC. Schedule IIID. Schedule IVList II (Underlying themes)I. Computation of DepreciationII. Code for Independent directorsIII. Memorandum of AssociationIV. Preparation of balance sheet and statement of profit and lossChoose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.A-II, B-I, C-IV, D-III
  • B.A-III, B-I, C-IV, D-II
  • C.A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II
  • D.A-I, B-III, C-II, D-IV
Correct Answer: A-III, B-I, C-IV, D-II

The correct match is as follows.

LIST I - LIST II

(Schedules under the companies Act, 2013) - (Underlying themes)

A. Schedule I - Memorandum of Association

B. Schedule II - Computation of Depreciation

C. Schedule III - Preparation of balance sheet and statement of profit and loss

D. Schedule IV - Code for independent directors

Question 38
On attaining the age of majority, a minor's agreement ____________.
  • A.Can be ratified by him
  • B.Cannot be ratified by him
  • C.Becomes void
  • D.Becomes valid
Correct Answer: Cannot be ratified by him

On attaining the age of majority, a minor's agreement cannot be ratified by him. A contract made with or by a minor is void ab-initio: A minor is not competent to contract and any agreement with or by a minor is void from the very beginning. A minor cannot ratify the agreement on attaining majority as the original agreement is void ab initio and a void agreement can never be ratified.

Question 39
From the operational point of view, which are the part of Environmental Audit?(a) Environment Management System Audit(b) Social Audit(c) Compliance Audit(d) Site Property Audit(e) Energy AuditChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.c, d and e only
  • B.a, c and d only
  • C.b, c and d only
  • D.a, d and e only
Correct Answer: a, c and d only

Let us consider the given options one by one.

 

(a) Environment Management System Audit: This is part of environmental audit as it assesses how well an organization's environmental management system is functioning, including its policies, procedures, and practices related to environmental sustainability.

 

(b) Social Audit: Social audit primarily focuses on an organization's social responsibility and impact on society. While it's related to corporate responsibility, it's not a direct part of environmental audit, which specifically deals with environmental concerns.

 

(c) Compliance Audit: Compliance audit is part of environmental audit because it evaluates whether an organization is complying with relevant environmental laws and regulations.

 

(d) Site Property Audit: Site property audit is typically part of environmental audit as it assesses the physical property and its impact on the environment.

 

(e) Energy Audit: While energy management is closely related to environmental sustainability, energy audit, in and of itself, is not considered a direct part of environmental audit. It focuses more on energy efficiency and consumption.

 

Therefore, correct answer is option B.

Question 40
A box-plot is a graphical summary measures of data that displays:a) Meanb)Q1c) Mediand)Q3e) ModeChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.c and e only
  • B.a, c and e only
  • C.c, d and b only
  • D.d, b and a only
Correct Answer: c, d and b only

Box plot is a method used for depicting groups of numerical data through their quartiles graphically.

Main components of a Box plot are:

 

Median: The line inside the box represents the median, which is the middle value of the dataset when it is ordered.

 

Quartiles: The box is divided into three parts by two lines. The bottom and top edges of the box represent the first quartile (Q1) and the third quartile (Q3), respectively. These quartiles divide the data into four equal parts.

 

Interquartile Range (IQR): The range between Q1 and Q13 is called the interquartile range. It is represented by the length of the box.

 

Thus, C is the correct answer.

Question 41
Who was of the opinion thatlaborwas “the father of wealth” and it must be included in any estimate of national wealth?
  • A.William Far
  • B.William Petty
  • C.William C. Pyle
  • D.Flamholtz
Correct Answer: William Petty

Option B is the correct answer.

 

William Petty, a 17th-century English economist and philosopher, made significant contributions to the understanding of economic principles and is known for his work on political arithmetic and early economic statistics. The phrase "labor is the father of wealth" reflects his emphasis on the importance of labor in the creation of wealth.

Question 42
In the process of perception, which one of the following is not an external factor influencing selection of stimuli?
  • A.Experience
  • B.Familiarity
  • C.Repetition
  • D.Novelty
Correct Answer: Experience

The correct answer is option A - Experience.

 

In the process of perception, experience is not considered an external factor influencing the selection of stimuli. Experience is a part of an individual's internal factors and cognitive processes that shape how they interpret and make sense of external stimuli. The other options listed—familiarity, repetition, and novelty—are indeed external factors that can impact how individuals perceive and select stimuli from their environment.

Question 43
As suggested by Collins, arrange the following leadership levels in sequentially higher order.a) The leader is a competent managerb) The leader is an executivec) The leader is a highly capable individuald) The leader is an effective leadere) The leader is a contributing team member.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.b, c, d, a, e
  • B.c, e, a, d, b
  • C.c, a, e, d, b
  • D.c, e, a, b, d
Correct Answer: c, e, a, d, b

Option B is the correct answer.

 

In Jim Collins' book "Good to Great," he introduces a hierarchy of leadership levels, with Level 5 Leadership being the highest and most effective form of leadership. Here are the five levels of leadership according to Collins:

 

Level 1 – Highly Capable Individual: At this level, leaders possess skills, capabilities, and knowledge that make them competent contributors. They excel in their individual roles and can produce high-quality work. However, their focus is primarily on their own performance and achievements.

 

Level 2 – Contributing Team Member: Leaders at this level not only excel individually but also contribute effectively to the success of their teams. They work well with others, collaborate, and help the team achieve its goals. While they have the ability to work in a group setting, their influence is limited to their team.

 

Level 3 – Competent Manager: Level 3 leaders are capable managers who can organize people and resources to achieve specific goals. They are effective in planning, organizing, and coordinating tasks, and they ensure that their teams meet their targets. However, their impact is often limited to their immediate sphere of influence.

 

Level 4 – Effective Leader: At this level, leaders go beyond management and start to influence and inspire others. They are able to create a sense of unity and shared purpose within their organizations. They may possess qualities like charisma and vision that help them rally their teams toward achieving larger goals.

 

Level 5 – Executive: This is the pinnacle of Collins' hierarchy. Level 5 leaders combine the qualities of all the previous levels, but what sets them apart is their humility and a deep sense of commitment to the organization's success. They are driven by a desire to see the organization thrive rather than seeking personal glory. They often attribute success to their team and take responsibility for failures themselves. This paradoxical blend of personal humility and professional will is what makes Level 5 leadership so powerful.

 

Collins' research showed that Level 5 leadership was a key factor in transforming good companies into great ones. The Level 5 leader's focus on the organization's success over personal recognition helps create a sustainable and enduring legacy for the company. It's important to note that Collins' model emphasizes a progression through these levels and highlights the importance of humility and a focus on the greater good in effective leadership.

Question 44
Substitution Effect is usually larger than the income effect in real world because:
  • A.Consumers
  • B.Consumer often consumes a small number of commodities.
  • C.Consumer only spends small portion of income on consumption.
  • D.Consumersincome is relatively smaller in relation to consumption.
Correct Answer: Consumers

Option A is the correct answer.

 

The Substitution Effect is generally larger than the income effect in the real world because consumers tend to be more responsive to changes in relative prices (substitution effect) than changes in real income (income effect). When the price of a good decreases, consumers may switch from relatively more expensive goods to the now cheaper good, leading to a larger impact on their choices compared to changes in overall purchasing power.

Question 45
Which one group of the following countries are members of ASEAN?
  • A.Laos, Cambodia,Brunei
  • B.Malaysia, Thailand, Taiwan
  • C.Myanmar, Singapore,Hong Kong
  • D.Fiji,Laos, Cambodia
Correct Answer: Laos, Cambodia,Brunei

Option A is the correct answer.

 

The Association of Southeast Asian Nations is a regional organization which was established to promote political and social stability amid rising tensions among the Asia-Pacific’s post-colonial states. The motto of ASEAN is “One Vision, One Identity, One Community”.

 

Member Nations – Indonesia; Malaysia; Philippines; Singapore; Thailand; Brunei; Vietnam; Laos; Myanmar; Cambodia

Question 46
Which one of the following values is NOT a part of OCTAPACE framework?
  • A.Openness
  • B.Extension
  • C.Proactivity
  • D.Autonomy
Correct Answer: Extension

Option B is the correct answer.

 

The OCTAPACE framework, developed by Udai Pareek, consists of eight core values that contribute to organizational culture and effectiveness. These values are:

O. Openness

C. Confrontation

T. Trust

A. Authenticity

P. Proactivity

A. Autonomy

C. Collaboration

E. Experimentation

 

The value that is NOT a part of the framework is option B - Extension.

Question 47
When the income of a minor child is clubbed with the income of mother or father, how much the deduction will be allowed to mother or father?
  • A.Rs. 1500
  • B.Rs. 2000
  • C.Actual income clubbed with the income of mother or father, whichever is less
  • D.No deduction
Correct Answer: Rs. 1500

Under the provisions of the Income Tax Act, 1961, if minor child's income is clubbed in the hands of parent, then exemption of Rs. 1,500 is allowed to the parent.

Question 48
For customers, which are the areas of ethical and social responsibility concerns?a) Product safetyb) Fair Pricec) Fair Wagesd) TQMe) Proper disclosures and informationChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.c and d only
  • B.c, d and e only
  • C.a and e only
  • D.a, b and e only
Correct Answer: a, b and e only

The correct answer is option D – a, b and e only.

 

The areas of ethical and social responsibility concerns for customers are:

a) Product safety

b) Fair Price

e) Proper disclosures and information

 

These areas highlight the responsibility of businesses to ensure the safety and quality of their products and to provide accurate and transparent information and price to customers.

Question 49
Under which of the following market structures, products are differentiated and close substitutes?a) Perfect competitionb) Monopolistic competitionc) Oligopolyd) Duopolye) MonopolyChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a, b and c only
  • B.b, c and d only
  • C.c, d and e only
  • D.a, c and d only
Correct Answer: b, c and d only

Option B is the correct answer.

 

Perfect competition is a market structure where there are many small firms producing identical products. The market is characterized by ease of entry and exit, perfect information, and a large number of buyers and sellers.

 

Monopolistic competition is a market structure where there are many firms producing similar but not identical products. Each firm has some degree of market power, and there is freedom of entry and exit.

 

Oligopoly is a market structure dominated by a small number of large firms that have the power to influence the market. The actions of one firm affect the others, and there are barriers to entry.

 

Duopoly is a specific form of oligopoly where there are only two dominant firms in the market. The decisions and actions of one firm directly impact the other, leading to strategic interactions.

 

Monopoly is a market structure where there is only one seller or producer that dominates the entire market. The monopolist has significant control over the price and quantity of the product.

Question 50
Match List IwithList II.List I (Motive of humanbehaviorin organizations)A) AchievementB) ControlC) ExtensionD) DependencyList II (Characteristic)I) Concern for othersII) Concern for self-developmentIII) Concern for excellenceIV) Concern for orderlinessChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-III, B-IV, C-II, D-I
  • B.A-IV, B-III. C-II, D-I
  • C.A-II, B-IV, C-I, D-III
  • D.A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II
Correct Answer: A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II

Option D is the correct answer.

 

A. Achievement – Concern for excellence

B. Control – Concern for orderliness

C. Extension – Concern for others

D. Dependency – Concern for self-development

Question 51
A point estimator is said to be consistent when:
  • A.It has smaller standard error
  • B.Its expected value is equal to the population parameter
  • C.It tends to become closer to the population parameter as the sample size become larger
  • D.It is based on all available information
Correct Answer: It tends to become closer to the population parameter as the sample size become larger

A consistent point estimator is one that, as the sample size increases, converges in probability to the true population parameter. In other words, it becomes more and more accurate as you gather more data.

Question 52
In case of two variables, the estimated regression equation isy^= 60 + 5x. The total sum of squares is 15730 and sum of square due to error is 1530. The estimated regression line based on this information is a:
  • A.Poorest fit
  • B.Moderate fit
  • C.Good fit
  • D.Best fit
Correct Answer: Good fit

R2 = 1 - SSESST = 1 - 153015730

= 0.903

R2 ≈ 0.902, which is close to 1. Therefore, the estimated regression line has a good fit.

Question 53
The doctrine of ‘Caveat emptor’ applies in which of the following situations?
  • A.When goods are sold by description
  • B.When goods are sold by sample
  • C.When goods are sold under implied conditions and warranties
  • D.When the buyer does not intimate the purpose to the seller and depends upon his own skill and judgment.
Correct Answer: When the buyer does not intimate the purpose to the seller and depends upon his own skill and judgment.

The principle of Caveat Emptor is explained in Section 16 of the Sale of Goods Act 1930 which states that there is no implied condition or warranty as to quality or fitness for any particular purpose of goods supplied.” Caveat Emptor means let the buyer beware.

 

However, following are the exceptions to the rule of ‘caveat emptor’:

 

1. Sec 16(1) talks about a situation where the buyer has either expressly or impliedly told the seller that he relies on his (seller) skills and judgements for a good that the seller deals in his ordinary course of business, then there is an implied condition that the goods shall reasonably be in accordance with the said purpose.

2. Sec. 16(2) talks about merchantable quality which is one more exception. It talks about the fact that the seller who sells goods by description has a duty to ensure that those goods are of proper merchantable quality i.e. if they are resold then they should be in a position to be passed of under the same market description. This however is subject to the condition that the buyer did not have reasonable opportunity to examine the goods. If he did then this would not apply.

3. Sec 16(3) provides for an exception where the conditions are implied by the usage of this particular trade. So, in a case there is an implied warranty with regards to the fitness and quality of the goods and seller doesn't abide by that then in that case, the seller would be liable.

4. In a case, where an order has been in bulk and the buyer checks only a small sample and then if the bulk doesn't coincide with the sample then the buyer won't be held responsible. For example, if one person orders a particular type of a notebook in a huge quantity and checks only one, and the others come out to be different then this doctrine won't be applicable.

5. The final exception to this rule applies to the scenario when the seller has obtained the consent of the buyer by fraud or misrepresentation then this doctrine would not apply. Moreover, if the seller willingly conceals any material defects which the buyer later comes to know about then also the buyer won't be liable.

 

Therefore, correct answer is option D.

Question 54
In totalitarianism, called authoritarianism, individual freedom is subordinated to the power of the authority of a group or state. Which of the following is NOT a type of totalitarianism?
  • A.Theocratic
  • B.Right Wing
  • C.Tribal
  • D.Conservative
Correct Answer: Conservative

The correct answer is option D - Conservative.

 

Conservatism is a political and social philosophy that emphasizes traditional values, institutions, and limited government intervention. It is not typically classified as a type of totalitarianism. The other options—Theocratic, Right Wing, and Tribal—can be associated with different forms of totalitarianism depending on their implementation and characteristics.

Question 55
Match List IwithList IIList I (Technique)A) PoolingB) Financial hedgeC) Natural hedgeD) NettingList II (Feature)I) Setting up production facilities in a number of countriesII) Reduction of Foreign exchange risk through leading and laggingIII) Simultaneous borrowing and lending in two different currenciesIV) Holding and managing of cash by the affiliatesChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-I, B-IV, C-II, D-III
  • B.A-IV, B-III, C-I, D-II
  • C.A-IV, B-II, C-III, D-1
  • D.A-I, B-II, C-III, D-IV
Correct Answer: A-IV, B-III, C-I, D-II

Pooling: Pooling refers to the centralization of funds or resources, and in this case, it involves holding and managing cash centrally by the affiliates.

 

Financial hedge: Financial hedging involves using financial instruments to offset or mitigate the risk of adverse price movements. In this context, simultaneous borrowing and lending in two different currencies can be a strategy to hedge against exchange rate risk.

 

Natural hedge: Natural hedging involves using the internal operations of a business to offset risks. In the context of foreign exchange risk, leading and lagging involve adjusting the timing of payments and receipts to offset the impact of currency fluctuations.

 

Netting: Netting refers to offsetting gains and losses or payments and receipts between different parts of a business. Setting up production facilities in multiple countries allows a company to net out risks and benefits associated with different markets.

Question 56
The sales step in which a salesperson learns as much as possible about a prospective customer before making a sales call is known as
  • A.Approach
  • B.Prospecting
  • C.Pre-approach
  • D.Presentation
Correct Answer: Pre-approach

The correct answer is option C - Pre-approach.

 

In the sales process, the step in which a salesperson learns as much as possible about a prospective customer before making a sales call is known as the "Pre-approach." This step involves gathering information about the customer's needs, preferences, demographics, and any relevant background information. This preparation helps the salesperson tailor their approach and presentation to the specific needs and interests of the customer.

Question 57
Which of the interventions can be used to manage the anxiety created by mergers and acquisitions?a) Speed-up of the integration processb) Articulate a new vision, common goals and organizational symbolsc) Employee counselling and stress management trainingd) Disengage efforts such as termination ceremoniese) Social support from spouse, friends, supervisors and co-workersChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.A, C and E only
  • D.A, B and E only
Correct Answer: A, C and E only

Option C is the correct answer. To reduce anxiety, emotional support is required which is given in statement a, c and e.

Question 58
Which one of the following normative ethical theories has “Net benefit from the decision” as consideration in ethical decision making?
  • A.Ethics of duty
  • B.Theory of justice
  • C.Stockholder ethics
  • D.Utilitarianism
Correct Answer: Utilitarianism

The correct answer is option D - Utilitarianism.

 

Utilitarianism is a normative ethical theory that emphasizes the greatest overall net benefit or utility as the basis for making ethical decisions. In utilitarianism, ethical action is the one that maximizes happiness, pleasure, or well-being for the greatest number of people while minimizing harm. Therefore, considering the "Net benefit from the decision" is a central consideration in ethical decision-making according to utilitarianism.

Question 59
The practice of setting a price target by the firm and then developing a product that would allow the firm to maximize total profits at that price is called:
  • A.Prestige pricing
  • B.Target Costing
  • C.Price matching
  • D.Value pricing
Correct Answer: Target Costing

Correct answer is option B.

 

The practice of setting a price target by the firm and then developing a product that would allow the firm to maximize total profits at that price is called "target costing."

 

Target costing flips the conventional process of initially designing a new product, determining its cost, and then questioning its market viability. Instead, it begins by establishing an ideal selling price rooted in customer value considerations and then sets cost targets to ensure the realization of that price.

Question 60
The Competition (Amendment) Act, 2023 revamped the Competition Act in which of the following perspectives?(a) The CCI needs to be intimated if the value of merger and acquisition deal exceedsRs. 2000 crores(b) The overall timeline for assessment of combination has been reduced to 150 days from 210 days(c) "Exclusive selling agreements" has been replaced with "exclusive dealing Agreement"(d) Entities who are not engaged in identical or similar trade shall also be part of an Anti-competitive Agreement under Section 3(3) of the Act(e) Anti-competitive conduct like "tie-up arrangements" "re-sale price Maintenance" and "exclusive distribution agreement" have been redefined.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a, b and c only
  • B.c and e only
  • C.a, b, c and d only
  • D.a, b, c, d and e
Correct Answer: a, b, c, d and e

The Competition (Amendment) Act, 2023 was recently passed in India. The Act makes a number of changes to the Competition Act, 2002, which is the country's primary competition law. The amendments aim to strengthen competition regulation, streamline operations, and foster a business-friendly environment.

 

Highlights of the major amendments under the Competition (Amendment) Act, 2023 are as follows.

 

1. Deal Value Threshold; Transaction value above Rs 2000 crore will require CCI’s approval

Section 5 of the Competition Act, 2002 deals with the Regulation of Combinations. The amendment act has amended section 5 of the Act by inserting a new clause that expands the scope of the CCI’s regulatory authority over combinations. The new clause states that the value of any transaction related to the acquisition of control, shares, voting rights or assets of an enterprise, merger or amalgamation that exceeds Rs. 2000 crore would require approval from the CCI. Further, this provision would apply only if the enterprise being acquired, taken control of, merged or amalgamated has substantial business operations in India, as specified by the regulations. This change is likely to have significant implications for large-scale mergers and acquisitions in India. By requiring CCI’s approval for transactions that exceed Rs 2000 crore threshold, the amendment seeks to ensure that such transactions do not result in anti-competitive practices and promote fair competition in the market.

 

2. Reduction of time limit for approval of combinations from 210 days to 150 days

As per section 6(2A) of the Competition Act, 2002, any combination shall not come into effect until 210 days have passed from the day on which the notice of the combination has been given to the Commission (CCI) or the Commission has passed an order, whichever is earlier. The amended section 6(2A) of the Competition Act, 2023 reduces the maximum time limit for approval of combinations from 210 days to 150 days. Thus, the CCI would have a maximum of 150 days from the date of notice of the combination to approve the combination or to pass an order. This will significantly reduce the waiting period for the approval of combinations. This would provide more expeditious approvals for combinations while ensuring a fair and transparent competition process.

 

3. Presumption to be part of the anti-competitive agreements in certain cases

Section 3 of the Competition Act provides for the prohibition of certain anti-competitive agreements.

Under the Act, anti-competitive agreements include any agreement related to the production, supply, storage, or control of goods or services, that can cause an appreciable adverse effect on competition in India. Any agreement between enterprises or persons engaged in identical or similar businesses will have such adverse effect on competition if it meets certain criteria.

 

These include:

(a) directly or indirectly determining purchase or sale prices,

(b) controlling production, supply, markets, or provision of services, or

(c) directly or indirectly leading to collusive bidding.

 

The amended norms introduce an additional provision stating that an enterprise or association of enterprises or a person or association of persons though not engaged in identical or similar trade shall also be presumed to be part of such anti-competitive agreements if they participate or intends to participate in the furtherance of such agreements. As per the amended norms, now it would be presumed that enterprises or persons not engaged in identical or similar businesses shall also be deemed to be part of the anti-competitive agreements, if they actively participate in the furtherance of such agreements.

 

4. Scope of anti-competitive agreements

The amendment to Section 3(4) of the Competition Act, 2002 has significantly enlarged the scope of anti-competitive agreements to now include indirect collusion. Now therefore, enterprises or persons not engaged in the trade of identical or similar businesses shall be presumed to be part of such agreements in case they participate or intend to participate in furtherance of such agreements. Further, the term 'exclusive supply agreement' has been replaced with 'exclusive dealing agreement' with the aim to cover acquisition and supply of all kinds of goods and services by an enterprise during the course of its business cycle.

 

5. Covering sales of goods and services

Anticompetitive conduct like “tie-in arrangement,” “refusal to deal,” “resale price maintenance,” and “exclusive distribution agreement” have all been redefined to cover goods and services, and not just goods.

 

6. Covering indirect restrictions

The “resale price maintenance” definition has been redefined to cover “any direct or indirect restriction”, not just an agreement.

 

7. Introduction of Limitation Period

The Competition (Amendment) Act also introduces a 3-year limitation period for entertaining information or references regarding alleged contraventions under the Act. The CCI is further empowered to condone delays in filing such information or references if sufficient cause is demonstrated. This limitation period imparts certainty and finality to competition law enforcement, preventing the reopening of cases long after the alleged contravention. It establishes a clear timeframe for parties to file complaints and ensures the timely execution of competition law enforcement.

 

8. Pre-deposit for filing of an appeal before the National Company Law Appellate Tribunal

Under the Amendment Act, 2023, any person aggrieved by the order passed by the Competition Commission of India, may file an appeal within 60 days from the date of the receipt of the Order, however, with a pre-deposit of 25% of the amount imposed by the Competition Commission of India, as per directions of the National Company Law Appellate Tribunal.

 

9. Penalties to be calculated upon "global turnover derived from all products and services"

Under the Amendment Act, 2023, the penalties can be imposed upon the global turnover derived from products and services by the Competition Commission of India. The same may lead to higher penalties by the Competition Commission of India after an enquiry into the agreements or abuse of a dominant position. Earlier, the penalties were imposed based upon the relevant turnover, which was presumed to be domestic turnover. Under the Amendment Act, 2023, the Competition Commission of India has the power to recover legal costs and the same shall be credited to Consolidated Funds of India.

 

10. Updated definition of ‘control’

One important change is the updated definition of "control," which now includes the concept of "material influence." This change acknowledges that having the ability to exert significant influence over the management, affairs, or strategic commercial decisions of an entity or group of entities is a key factor in determining control. The Competition Commission of India (CCI) has the authority to establish additional criteria, through regulations, to clarify what constitutes "material influence." This addition aims to provide clearer guidelines on what control means and reduce uncertainty when determining its extent in various business arrangements.

 

11. Introduction of Settlements and Commitments

Finally, the amendment introduces a settlement and commitment mechanism for enterprises under inquiry for abuse of dominance or anti-competitive agreements. This framework provides enterprises with the opportunity to seek resolution through mutually agreed remedies or commitments, thereby promoting cooperation and expediting dispute resolution. The specific procedure for settlements and commitments will be outlined in regulations, aligning Indian competition law with international best practices. This new mechanism aims to reduce the time and resources expended on lengthy investigations and litigation, fostering efficient and compliant business practices.

 

12. Issuance of Statement of objections and modifications

The Amendment Act, 2023, empowers the Competition Commission of India to issue a statement of objections, if it is of the opinion that a combination has or is likely to have an adverse effect upon the competition in the market. The Commission may issue a statement of objections to the concerned party and direct them to explain within 45 days as to why the combination is to be allowed. The concerned party may approach the Commission with suitable modifications to eliminate the adverse effect of the combination to the market.

 

13. Power to Competition Commission of India to appoint Director General

Under the Amendment Act 2023, the Competition Commission of India has the power to appoint the Director General for assisting in investigating/enquiry into contravention of the provisions of the Competition Act.

 

The Amendment Act, 2023 also provides for more investigating powers to the Director General for conducting the enquiry, including examination of any officer/agent of the party being investigated with the prior approval of the Competition Commission of India. The Amendment Act, 2023 also provides for power to the Competition Commission of India to call upon experts to provide expert opinions.

Question 61
Which of the following describe an intervention currency?
  • A.The currency in which exporter choose to invoice their exports
  • B.The currency in which cross-border transactions are paid for and closed
  • C.The currency in terms of which a domestic currency is quoted
  • D.The vehicle currency
Correct Answer: The currency in terms of which a domestic currency is quoted

Option C is the correct answer.

An intervention currency refers to a currency that a central bank or monetary authority actively buys or sells in the foreign exchange market to influence its value. The intervention is a deliberate action taken by the monetary authorities to stabilize or manipulate the exchange rate of their currency in the foreign exchange market.

Question 62
Given below are two statements:Statement I:Certificate of incorporation is conclusive evidence that all the requirements of the Companies Act have been complied with in respect of registration.Statement II:After incorporation, if the company makes a fresh contract in terms of the pre-incorporation contract, the liability of the promoters shall come to an end.In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are true
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement are false
  • C.Statement I is true but Statement II is false
  • D.Statement I is false but Statement II is true
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are true

Statement I is correct. A Certificate of incorporation issued by the registrar shall be conclusive evidence that:

(a) all the requirements of the Companies Act have been complied with in respect of to be registration;

(b) the association is a company authorized to be registered;

(c) the association has been duly registered under the Companies Act.

 

The term ‘conclusive evidence’ means that no inquiry shall be allowed to be made regarding the correctness or incorrectness of any particulars contained in the certificate of incorporation.

 

Statement II is also correct. Contracts made by promoters who act as agents or trustees of the company before its incorporation, are called pre-incorporation contracts. Such contracts cannot bind the company because the company has no legal status prior to its incorporation.

 

Promoters can be personally held responsible for contracts made on behalf of a not-yet-established company. Even if the contract states that only the company is responsible, promoters may still be liable for damages if the promises are not fulfilled (Scot v. Lord Ebury). In Kelner v. Baxter, it was affirmed that promoters signing contracts are personally liable.

 

Once a company is formed, it cannot retroactively approve or benefit from contracts made by promoters before incorporation. The company can, however, choose to enter into a new contract after its establishment, based on the terms of the pre-incorporation contract. It's advisable for promoters to include in the contract that if the company makes a new contract, the promoters' liability ends, and if the company doesn't do so within a specified time, either party can cancel the contract.

Question 63
Arrange the following service gaps as per SERVQUAL approach in the logical sequence.a) The gap between service quality specifications and service deliveryb) The gap between the customer's expectations and management perceptionc) The gap between perceived service and expected serviced) The gap between management perception and service quality specificatione) The gap between service delivery and external communications.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.d, a, b, e, c
  • B.b, d, a, e, c
  • C.a, c, b, d, e
  • D.c, a, b, e, d
Correct Answer: b, d, a, e, c

Option B is the correct answer.

 

SERVQUAL is a widely used framework and methodology for assessing and measuring the quality of services provided by organizations. Developed by Parasuraman, Zeithaml, and Berry in the late 1980s, SERVQUAL stands for "Service Quality" and "Quality of Service," reflecting its focus on understanding customer perceptions and expectations regarding the quality of services they receive. The SERVQUAL framework consists of a questionnaire-based approach that helps organizations identify gaps between customer expectations and perceptions of the actual service delivered. These gaps provide valuable insights into areas where improvements are needed to enhance the quality of services and customer satisfaction.

 

The SERVQUAL framework comprises 5 dimensions, often referred to as the "GAP" model:

 

Gap 1 – Knowledge Gap (Expected Service vs. Management's Perception): This gap represents the difference between customer expectations and what management perceives those expectations to be. It emphasizes the importance of understanding and aligning with customer expectations.

 

Gap 2 – Policy Gap (Management's Perception vs. Service Specification): This gap refers to the difference between management's perception of customer expectations and the actual service specifications or standards set by the organization. It highlights the importance of clearly defining and communicating service standards.

 

Gap 3 – Delivery Gap (Service Specification vs. Service Delivery): This gap represents the difference between the service specifications and the actual service delivered. It underscores the need for consistent and accurate execution of services according to established standards.

 

Gap 4 – Communication Gap (Service Delivery vs. External Communication): This gap reflects the difference between the service delivered and how the service is communicated to customers. It emphasizes the importance of accurate and transparent communication about services.

 

Gap 5 – Perception Gap (Expected Service vs. Perceived Service): This final gap is the difference between customer expectations and their perceptions of the service they receive. It highlights the customer's assessment of whether the service met their expectations.

 

The SERVQUAL framework involves administering a survey questionnaire to customers to assess their perceptions and expectations across the five dimensions. Customers rate various aspects of the service on a Likert scale, allowing organizations to quantify the gaps and identify areas that require improvement. By analyzing the gaps between customer expectations and perceptions, organizations can identify specific areas for improvement in their service delivery processes, customer communication, and overall service quality.

Question 64
Which of the following are the characteristics of the Euro Currency Market?a) The euro currency market does not have geographical limitsb) The euro currency market is unregulatedc) The euro currency market does not have deposit insuranced) There are no restriction on the maximum interest payable or chargeable.e) The euro currency market does not attract CRR and SLR restrictions.Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.a, b and c only
  • B.b, e and d only
  • C.e, c and a only
  • D.d, a and e only
Correct Answer: e, c and a only

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Eurocurrency is a currency that is deposited at a foreign bank outside of its home country. Contrary to its name, the term does not refer to euros that are deposited outside of Europe. It is a general term that applies to all currencies that are deposited anywhere outside of its local country. For example, if you deposit Japanese yen at a bank in the United States, it is considered to be Eurocurrency.

 

The market for Euro currency is the money market for currency outside the country where it is a legal tender. Banks, MNC's, mutual funds, and hedge funds make use of the Eurocurrency market. They want to avoid regulatory standards, tax rules, and interest rate limits that are commonly present in domestic banking.

 

Significance

In the Eurocurrency market, interest rates paid on deposits are typically higher than on the domestic market. This is because the depositor is not protected by the same national banking laws and has no government insurance on deposits. Tariffs on Eurocurrency loans are typically lower for essentially the same reasons than those in the domestic market. Nor Eurocurrency bank accounts are subject to the same reserve requirements as domestic accounts.

 

The main advantage of Euro currency markets is that they are more competitive. At the same time, they will give borrowers lower interest rates and higher interest rates for lenders. That is mostly due to less regulated Eurocurrency markets. On the downside, Eurocurrency markets are facing higher risks.

Question 65
The Directorate General of Foreign Trade (DGFT) facilitates and promotes foreign trade in India and also implements the foreign trade policy of India. Which of the following union ministry governs the DGFT?
  • A.Ministry of Commerce and Industry
  • B.Ministry of Science and Technology
  • C.Ministry of Finance
  • D.Ministry of External Affairs
Correct Answer: Ministry of Commerce and Industry

Option A is the correct answer.

Question 66
Match List I with the List II.List I (HerfindahlIndex Value)A. ZeroB. 0-1,000C. 1,000-1,800D. 1,800-10,000List II (Market Type)I. Oligopoly with high risk of CartelsII. OligopolyIII. Monopolistic competitionIV. Extremely competitive marketChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-I, B-II, C-III, D-IV
  • B.A-IV, B-III, C-II, D-I
  • C.A-II, B-I, C-III, D-IV
  • D.A-I, B-III, C-II, D-IV
Correct Answer: A-IV, B-III, C-II, D-I

Option B is the correct answer.

 

The Herfindahl-Hirschman Index (HHI) is a common measure of market concentration and is used to determine market competitiveness, often pre- and post-merger and acquisition (M&A) transactions. The index measures the size of companies relative to the size of the industry they are in and the amount of competitiveness. The HHI is calculated by squaring the market share of each firm competing in a market and then summing the resulting numbers. It can range from close to 0 to 10,000, with lower values indicating a less concentrated market.

Question 67
Which of the following cause demand of a product to increase?a) An increase in consumer's income.b) An increase in the prices of substitutes.c) An increase in the price of complements.d) An increase in the number of substitutes.e) An increased taste for the commodity.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a, b and c only
  • B.c,d and e only
  • C.b,d and e only
  • D.a, b and e only
Correct Answer: a, b and e only

The factors that cause the demand for a product to increase are:

  • An increase in consumer's income (a)
  • An increase in the number of substitutes (d)
  • An increased taste for the commodity (e)

Therefore, the correct answer is option D.

Question 68
Given below are two statements: One is labelled as Assertion A and the other is labelled as Reason R.Assertion ‘A’:When a partner retires, all the assets and liabilities are revalued according to current value.Reason ‘R’:The balance sheet should show the correct values of assets and liabilities.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R are correct but R is not the correct explanation of A
  • C.A is correct but R is not correct
  • D.A is not correct but R is correct
Correct Answer: Both A and R are correct but R is not the correct explanation of A

Assertion A states that when a partner retires, all the assets and liabilities are revalued according to the current value. This assertion is correct because when a partner leaves a partnership firm, it's essential to determine the current value of the assets and liabilities to settle the partner's share of the partnership.

 

Reason R states that the balance sheet should show the correct values of assets and liabilities. This reason is also correct because a balance sheet is a financial statement that provides an accurate representation of a company's financial position, including the values of assets and liabilities.

 

However, while both Assertion A and Reason R are correct, they are not related to each other.

Question 69
Which are the appropriate tax planning perspectives in case of shut down or continue decision under Income Tax Act, 1961?(a) Business loss and unabsorbed depreciation can be carry forward and set off against profit and gain.(b) The loss making company and profit making company may merge to avail the tax benefit(c) Tax benefit of deduction u/s 33 AB and 115 VT may be withdrawn and liable to tax for the year in which business is discontinued.(d) The condition of section 80 IB / 80 IC of the Act, a deduction is allowed to such undertaking(e) If a person has more than one business, the loss making business may not be discontinued.Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.a, c and d only
  • B.b, d and e only
  • C.c, d and e only
  • D.a, c and e only
Correct Answer: a, c and e only

When a business suffers loss continuously, whatever reasons of loss may be, the management has to decide whether the business should shut down or continue. While taking this decision, the impact of Income tax provisions should not be over looked.

 

Various tax planning considerations are as follows.

 

(i) If the business is discontinued, the business losses and unabsorbed depreciation still can be carry forwarded and set off against profits and gains of business or profession. (in the case of unabsorbed depreciation – set off against income under any head).

(ii) The benefit of deductions under section 33AB (Tea Development Account/ Coffee Development Account/ Rubber Development Account) and 115VT (Reserve for shipping business) may be withdrawn and liable to tax for the year in which business is discontinued.

(iii) If the business is discontinued and the assets used for scientific research and family planning are sold, the selling price to the extent of deduction claimed shall be deemed as the profits of the previous year in which such assets are sold.

(iv) If a person is running more than one business the loss making business should not be discontinued but operated in a minimal way so that the losses and expenses like retrenchment compensation, interest on borrowed funds, bad debts etc. adjusted with profit making units.

 

Therefore, correct answer is option D.

Question 70
Match List IwithList IIList I (Non-Parametric Test)A) Friedman TestB) Mann-Whitney U TestC)KruskalWallis TestD) Wilcoxon signed Rank TestList II (Parametric test)I) One-way ANOVAII) t-testIII) Paired t-testIV) two-way ANOVAChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-I, B-III, C-IV, D-II
  • B.A-IV, B-II, C-I, D-III
  • C.A-III, B-I, C-II, D-IV
  • D.A-II, B-IV, C-III, D-I
Correct Answer: A-IV, B-II, C-I, D-III

The Friedman test is a non-parametric test used for analyzing randomized block design experiments with more than two related groups. It's an extension of the Wilcoxon signed-rank test to more than two groups. The parametric counterpart for analyzing the influence of two independent variables on a dependent variable is the Two-way ANOVA.

 

The Mann-Whitney U test is a non-parametric alternative to the independent samples t-test. Both tests are used to compare the means of two independent groups, with the Mann-Whitney U test being appropriate when the assumption of normality is not met.

 

The Kruskal-Wallis test is a non-parametric alternative to the one-way ANOVA. Both tests are used to compare the means of three or more independent groups, with the Kruskal-Wallis test being appropriate when the assumption of normality is not met.

 

The Wilcoxon signed-rank test is a non-parametric alternative to the paired t-test. Both tests are used to compare the means of two related groups, with the Wilcoxon signed-rank test being appropriate when the assumption of normality is not met.

Question 71
According to the theory of contestable markets, vigorous competition can take place even among few sellers if ______ and _______.a) Product is differentiatedb) Demand is infinitely elasticc) Entry into the market is absolutely freed) There are strong entry-exit barrierse) Exit from the market is entirely costless.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a and d only
  • B.b and e only
  • C.a and c only
  • D.c and e only
Correct Answer: c and e only

Option D is the correct answer.

 

The contestable market theory is an economic concept stating that companies with few rivals behave in a competitive manner when the market they operate in has weak barriers to entry. The theory assumes that even in a monopoly or oligopoly, incumbents will act competitively when there is a lack of barriers, such as government regulation and high entry costs, doing everything they can to prevent new entrants from one day putting them out of business.

Question 72
A population has a mean of 200 and a standard deviation of 50. Suppose a simple random sample of size 100 is selected then the probability that the sample mean will be ± 5 of the population mean is:
  • A.0.7523
  • B.0.6928
  • C.0.9544
  • D.0.6826
Correct Answer: 0.6826

Standard error of the mean (SEM) = σn = 50100 = 5

z = ±55 = ± 1

P(-1 < z < 1) = 0.6826

Question 73
Given below are two statements: One is labelled as Assertion A and the other is labelled as Reason R.Assertion A:By removing barriers between national markets, tradingblockscreate competition due to bigger trading area.Reason R:Increased competition can lead to the closure of local industry and harm domestic consumption.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R are correct but R is not the correct explanation of A
  • C.A is correct but R is not correct
  • D.A is not correct but R is correct
Correct Answer: A is correct but R is not correct

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Assertion is correct but Reason is incorrect. Increased competition does not necessarily leads to closure of local industry but increase of efficiency of local markets.

Question 74
Match List IwithList IIList I (Consequent outcome)A. The person is liable to penalty and prosecutionB. Tax is reduced by taking advantage of loopholes of the lawC. Main aim is compliance with legal formalitiesD. It is a guide in decision makingList II (Taxation Perspective)I. Tax ManagementII. Tax AvoidanceIII. Tax EvasionIV. Tax planningChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-II, B-III, C-IV, D-I
  • B.A-II. B-IV, C-III, D-I
  • C.A-III, B-II, C-I, D-IV
  • D.A-III. B-I, C-IV, D-II
Correct Answer: A-III, B-II, C-I, D-IV

Tax Management refers to the process of efficiently managing one's tax affairs to ensure compliance with the law and minimize tax liability while staying within the legal framework. It is mainly focused on compliance and avoiding penalties or prosecution.

 

Tax Avoidance involves reducing tax liability by exploiting legal methods, including the use of tax planning strategies or taking advantage of loopholes in the tax law. It aims to minimize tax payments within the bounds of the law.

 

Tax Evasion is the illegal act of intentionally not reporting income or inflating deductions to reduce tax liability. It results in penalties and potential prosecution.

 

Tax Planning is the process of proactively arranging one's financial affairs to legally reduce tax liability. It involves making informed decisions to minimize tax while staying compliant with the law.

 

Based on above explanation, following is the correct match:

1.The person is liable to penalty and prosecution corresponds to Tax Evasion.

2.Tax is reduced by taking advantage of loopholes of the law corresponds to Tax Avoidance.

3. Main aim is compliance with legal formalities corresponds to Tax Management.

4. It is a guide in decision making corresponds to Tax Planning.

 

So, option C is the correct answer.

Question 75
Which are the RBI notified domestic accredited credit rating agencies?a) Brickwork Ratingsb)AcuiteRatingsc) CRISIL Ratingsd) Standard and Poor’se) Moody’sChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.b and c only
  • B.c and d only
  • C.a and c only
  • D.c and e only
Correct Answer: b and c only

Option A is the correct answer.

 

In a notification released by the RBI in January 2023, banks are advised to use the ratings of the following domestic credit rating agencies for risk weighting their claims for capital adequacy purposes:

a. Acuite Ratings & Research Limited (Acuite)

b. Credit Analysis and Research Limited (CARE);

c. CRISIL Ratings Limited;

d. ICRA Limited;

e. India Ratings and Research Private Limited (India Ratings); and

f. INFOMERICS Valuation and Rating Pvt Ltd. (INFOMERICS)

 

Brickwork Ratings was dropped.

Question 76
From the followings which is an uncommon feature of Private Equity and Venture Capital?
  • A.Both invest in companies that are not able to or ready to gain capital from the public
  • B.Their investment is used for financial or operating restructuring of the investor companies
  • C.They are set up an independent pool of capital contributed by institutions or the high-net-worth individuals
  • D.Their activities are subject to few regulations
Correct Answer: Their investment is used for financial or operating restructuring of the investor companies

Option B is the correct answer.

 

While Private Equity firms often invest in companies with the intention of improving their financial and operational performance, Venture Capital firms usually focus on providing funding for early-stage companies to help them grow and scale. Financial or operating restructuring is more commonly associated with Private Equity.

Question 77
Which one of the following is a fully owned subsidiary of the RBI?
  • A.Indian Institute of Bank Management (IIBM)
  • B.National Institute of Bank Management (NIBM)
  • C.Indian Institute of Banking and Finance (IIBF)
  • D.Indian Financial Technology and Allied Services (IFTAS)
Correct Answer: Indian Financial Technology and Allied Services (IFTAS)

Option D is the correct answer.

 

Indian Financial Technology & Allied Services (IFTAS) is a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Reserve Bank of India that designs, deploys & provides the essential IT-related services, required by the Reserve Bank of India, banks, and financial institutions.

Question 78
Starting from the earliest, sequence the steps taken to develop the money market in India.a) Introduction of Interest Rate Swaps (IRSs)b) Introduction of Commercial Paperc) Introduction of Ways and Means Advances (WMA) linked to bank rated) Introduction of Liquidity Adjustment Facility (LAF)e) Implementation of Real Time Gross Settlement (RTGS)Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.c, b, d, a, e
  • B.d, c, b, e, a
  • C.b, d, c, a, e
  • D.b, c, d, a, e
Correct Answer: b, c, d, a, e

The development of the money market in India occurred over several stages. Let's sequence the steps:

  • Introduction of Commercial Paper (CP): Commercial Paper was introduced as a money market instrument to provide short-term funds to corporations.
  • Introduction of Ways and Means Advances (WMA) linked to bank rate: Ways and Means Advances (WMA) linked to the bank rate were introduced to help the government manage its short-term financial needs.
  • Introduction of Liquidity Adjustment Facility (LAF): LAF was introduced to control liquidity in the market through repo and reverse repo operations.
  • Introduction of Interest Rate Swaps (IRSs): Interest Rate Swaps (IRSs) were introduced as financial derivatives to manage interest rate risks.
  • Implementation of Real-Time Gross Settlement (RTGS): RTGS was implemented for electronic funds transfer in real-time.
Question 79
The optimal capital budget of a firm is reflected by intersection point of:
  • A.Security market line and capital market line
  • B.Weighted average cost of capital curve and marginal cost of capital curve
  • C.Investment opportunity curve and marginal cost of capital curve
  • D.Weighted average cost of capital curve and investment opportunity curve.
Correct Answer: Investment opportunity curve and marginal cost of capital curve

Option C is the correct answer.

 

The Optimal Capital Budget is an amount of investment that allows shareholder value to be maximized. It can be determined by plotting the marginal cost of capital (MCC) schedule and the investment opportunity schedule (IOS) in the same graph. The intersection point of the MCC curve and the IOS curve is the optimal capital budget.

Question 80
The total return for an equity stock during a year was 12.5 %. The rate of inflation during that year was 3.5 %. The real (inflation-adjusted) return was:
  • A.9.26 %
  • B.16.00 %
  • C.7.65 %
  • D.8.70 %
Correct Answer: 8.70 %

Real return = 1+Nominal Return1+Rate of inflation – 1

= 1+0.1251+0.035 – 1 ≈ 8.7%

Question 81
Which of the following is not the limitation of activity-based costing?
  • A.It involves various support activities in the process of making products.
  • B.It does not provide relevant information for decision making.
  • C.All costs cannot be identified easily with a particular activity
  • D.Set up cost as well as costs of running and updating the ABC system are very high.
Correct Answer: It involves various support activities in the process of making products.

ABC Costing recognizes that products or services often consume resources from multiple support activities in the production process. These support activities can include setup, quality control, material handling, and other overhead functions. By involving and considering these various support activities, ABC provides a more precise and granular breakdown of costs. This accurate allocation helps in understanding the true cost of each product or service.

 

By adopting a more forensic approach to assigning overheads, ABC can provide a more accurate cost figure for each unit of output. This should help in assessing product profit- ability and in making pricing and product mix decisions. ABC can also help managers gain a better understanding of business operations. This, in turn, should help improve performance.

 

Despite its apparent advantages, critics point out that ABC can be a costly exercise. Setting up the costing system, as well as updating it, can consume a great deal of resources. Running an ABC system can also be complex and time-consuming, particularly where business operations involve a large number of activities and cost drivers. Management reports generated from a complex costing system are also likely to be com- plex. If managers find these reports difficult to understand, the potential benefits of employing ABC may be lost.

 

Where products or services have similar levels of output involving similar activities and processes, or where overheads form a relatively low proportion of the total costs, the more accurate measurements provided by ABC are unlikely to lead to strikingly different outcomes from those obtained under the traditional approach. As a result, opportunities for better pricing, planning and cost control may be few. If this were the case, switching to an ABC system would be difficult to justify.

 

Measurement and tracing problems may arise with ABC. Not all costs can be easily traced to a particular activity. Nevertheless, all activity costs have to be assigned to one cost pool or another. To ensure that all these costs are considered, some may be assigned to cost pools on an arbitrary basis. Poor quality data on activity costs may also lead to arbitrary cost assignments. A final problem is that the relationship between activity costs and their cost drivers may be difficult to determine. Identifying a cause-and-effect relationship can be difficult where activity costs are fixed and do not change with changes in operating activities. Finally, ABC is criticized for the same reason that traditional full costing is criticised – it does not provide relevant information for decision making.

 

Thus, based on above explanation, option A is the correct answer.

Question 82
In the context of banking sector, ‘Spread’ is defined as a function of the following:a) Forexb) Net Interest Incomec) Rate Sensitive Assetsd) Asset Ratioe) Leverage RatioChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.c and e only
  • B.a and c only
  • C.b and d only
  • D.b and e only
Correct Answer: b and d only

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Spread in banking is known as the difference between the interest rate that a bank charges from a borrower and the interest rate a bank pays to the depositor. Bank spread is the gap of interest rate that the bank takes from the borrower and the interest bank pays to the depositor. Spread rate shows the profit margin of the bank.

 

A bank earns money from interest it receives on loans and other assets, and it pays out money to customers who make deposits into interest-bearing accounts. The ratio of money it receives to money it pays out is called the bank spread.

Question 83
Which Committee had recommended a comprehensive framework of reform in the insurance sector?
  • A.Ghosh Committee (1993)
  • B.SodhaniCommittee (1994)
  • C.Malhotra Committee (1993)
  • D.KaliaCommittee (1994)
Correct Answer: Malhotra Committee (1993)

Option C is the correct answer.

 

In 1993, the Government set up a committee under the chairmanship of RN Malhotra, former Governor of RBI, to propose recommendations for reforms in the insurance sector. The objective was to complement the reforms initiated in the financial sector.

Question 84
﻿"It is an art of dodging tax without actually breaking the law". This is related with:
  • A.Tax Management
  • B.Tax Avoidance
  • C.Tax Planning
  • D.Tax Evasion
Correct Answer: Tax Avoidance

Role of judiciary on the concept of Tax Avoidance can be traced back on the judgment which was pronounced by Justice Chinnapa Reddy’s in the Mcdowell’s Case. This case defines the distinction between the term tax avoidance and tax evasion in a crisp manner, it defines Tax Avoidance as “the art of dodging tax without breaking the law.” On the other hand, tax evasion is a crime in which an individual or a business entity intentionally underpays or hide their certain amount of income in order to save more amount of taxes. This method is certainly illegal in all the countries.

Question 85
In which of the following balance of payment (BoP) accounts changes in holdings of gold and foreign currencies by official monetary institutions are accounted for?
  • A.Current Account
  • B.Capital Account
  • C.Official Reserves Account
  • D.Foreign Exchange Account
Correct Answer: Official Reserves Account

Option C is the correct answer.

 

The Balance of Payments (BoP) is a systematic record of a country's economic transactions with the rest of the world. It is divided into several accounts, and one of these accounts is the Official Reserves Account.

 

Current Account: This account records the country's transactions in goods and services, income, and current transfers. It reflects the nation's trade balance, net income from abroad, and net current transfers.

 

Capital Account: This account captures the flow of capital into and out of a country. It includes transactions in financial instruments such as foreign direct investment and portfolio investment.

 

Official Reserves Account: This account deals with changes in a country's official reserves, specifically gold and foreign currencies held by the central bank or other official monetary institutions. When a country's central bank buys or sells foreign currencies or gold, these transactions are reflected in the Official Reserves Account.

Question 86
The steps to be followed by a firm while strategizing to go international are as follows:a) Deciding when to enterb) Deciding which markets to enterc) Deciding whether to go globald) Choosing a mode of entrye) Deciding how to enter the chosen market.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.e, d, c, b, a
  • B.c, a, e, d, b
  • C.c, b, a, e, d
  • D.a, b, c, e, d
Correct Answer: c, b, a, e, d

Option C is the correct answer.

 

The correct sequence of steps to be followed by a firm while strategizing to go international is:

  • Deciding whether to go global (c)
  • Deciding which markets to enter (b)
  • Deciding when to enter (a)
  • Deciding how to enter the chosen market (e)
