Choosing a mode of entry (d)

Question 87
Which of the following are correct for Agricultural Income?(a) Income from self-grown grass, trees, bamboo(b) Rent and Rates derived from land(c) Income from making the produce fit for marketing(d) Income from land used for storing agriculture produce(e) Income from farmhouseChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.b, c and e only
  • B.b, d and e only
  • C.a, c and d only
  • D.c, d and e only
Correct Answer: b, c and e only

The term ‘Agricultural Income’ has been defined under Section 2(1A) of the Income Tax Act, 1961. As per this section, ‘Agricultural Income’ is:

Any rent or revenue derived from land, which is situated in India, and is used for agricultural purposes.

Any income derived from such land by agricultural operations including processing of the agricultural produce raised or received rent-in-kind so as to render it fit for the market for sale of such produce;

Income attributable to a farmhouse subject to satisfaction of certain conditions.

Income derived from saplings or seedlings grown in a nursery.

 

Thus, option A is correct.

Question 88
The problem-definition process involves following steps. Arrange them in a logical Sequence.a) Determine the unit of analysisb) Determine the relevant variablesc) Write managerial decision statement and research objectivesd) Write research question and/or research hypothesise) Identify key problemsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a, b, e, d, c
  • B.c, d, a, b, e
  • C.b, e, a, c, d
  • D.e, c, a, b, d
Correct Answer: e, c, a, b, d

Option D is the correct answer.

Question 89
Which one of the following is the hiring related turnover cost when an employee quits an organization?
  • A.Advertising
  • B.Interviewing
  • C.Training
  • D.Recruiter fees
Correct Answer: Training

Option C – Training is the correct answer.

 

This is the correct answer. Training costs are incurred when a new employee is hired to replace the departing employee. The organization invests resources to onboard and train the new employee, which includes orientation, job-specific training, and potentially mentoring. These costs contribute to the overall expenses resulting from employee turnover.

Question 90
A multinational company can use which prices to create profits in low tax regimes and loss in high tax regimes?
  • A.Divisional prices
  • B.Inter-Divisional Prices
  • C.Holding company prices
  • D.Transfer prices
Correct Answer: Transfer prices

Option D is the correct answer.

 

A multinational company can use transfer prices to manipulate profits in different tax jurisdictions. Transfer pricing involves setting the prices for transactions between different divisions or entities within the same multinational company. By adjusting these prices, a company can potentially shift profits to locations with lower tax rates, allowing them to reduce their overall tax liability. This practice, when used to exploit tax differences between jurisdictions, can lead to concerns about tax avoidance and has implications for international tax regulations.

Question 91
An attacking strategy which involves introducing new products or technologies that rewrite the rules of competition in the market and avoid direct conflict with a rival is known as
  • A.Flanking
  • B.Bypass
  • C.Encirclement
  • D.Guerrilla
Correct Answer: Bypass

Correct answer is option B - Bypass.

 

The attacking strategy that involves introducing new products or technologies to rewrite the rules of competition in the market and avoid direct conflict with a rival is known as "Bypass" strategy.

Question 92
Read the passage and choose the correct answer from the options given below.﻿Interoperability guidelines for prepaid payment instruments with United Payments Interface (UPI) bolster the business case for digital wallets. For a loading fee on transactions through UPI, payments banks, for instance, can widen the adoption of wallets among customers and merchants. This increase use cases for UPI, which largely works on a model of free peer- to- peer- merchant transactions. The opportunity provided by the scorching growth of UPI transactions must, however, cross the hurdle of consumerbehaviorthat is shaped by zero fees for payments made from their bank accounts. For survival, payments banks - which can accept deposits but are prohibited from lending, need to be part of the UPI ecosystem. They also need to carve out a distinct business segment where they have an advantage over full-service banks.Those use cases are expected to grow as UPI diversifies into cross-border remittances, introduces consumer lending throughRuPaycredit cards and offers currency exchange to foreigntravelers, and bill payments using standing instructions gain traction. UPI will also have to integrate with the digital rupee that is undergoing tests for retail and wholesale transactions. The digital payments platform will continue to play a key role in the infrastructure that is being developed around contactless payments.This involves building additional UPI context around digital transactions such as billing and credit- profiling. Initial adoption has surpassed the most optimistic expectations. But that is principally on account of the waiver of the merchant discount rate. In the next leg, UPI will grow by providing solutions for the conduct of business. It will have to incorporate lending at some point to become a comprehensive medium of commerce. The infrastructure must encourage fin-techs to push innovation in finance. Payments banks have a strong correlation with the growth of digital transactions. They are vital piece of the machinery being built. The interoperability with UPI guidelines plugs them deeper.Which of the following use cases are expected to promote the growth of payment basses?a) UPI integration with the digital rupeeb) Dislocation of payment banks from digital transactionsc) UPI facilitation of cross-border remittancesd) Keeping a safe distance from the contactless payment infrastructuree) Consumer lending throughRupayCredit Cards.Choose the most appropriate answer from the operations given below:
  • A.a, b and c only
  • B.c, d and e only
  • C.a, c and e only
  • D.b, d and e only
Correct Answer: a, c and e only

The use cases that are expected to promote the growth of payment banks are:

 

(a) UPI integration with the digital rupee

(c) UPI facilitation of cross-border remittances

(e) Consumer lending through RuPay Credit Cards

 

So, the most appropriate answer is option C - a, c and e only.

  • C.Integration with the UPI ecosystem
  • D.Integration with the full-service banks

Question 94

Question 95

Question 96
Read the passage and choose the correct answer from the options given below:﻿Interoperability guidelines for prepaid payment instruments with United Payments Interface (UPI) bolster the business case for digital wallets. The opportunity provided by the scorching growth of UPI transactions must, however, cross the hurdle of consumerbehaviorthat is shaped by zero fees for payments made from their bank accounts. They also need to carve out a distinct business segment where they have an advantage over full-service banks.Those use cases are expected to grow as UPI diversifies into cross-border remittances, introduces consumer lending throughRuPaycredit cards and offers currency exchange to foreigntravelers, and bill payments using standing instructions gain traction. UPI will also have to integrate with the digital rupee that is undergoing tests for retail and wholesale transactions.   • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect

Question 97
Read the passage and choose the correct answer from the options given below:The proposed facility similar to the Applications Supported by Blocked Amount (ASBA) for secondary markets has elements to protect investors while increasing their potential earnings. The way it works now in the primary market is that money remains blocked in investor accounts, earning interest till issues of Initial Public Offerings (IPO) accept subscriptions. Replicating this for the secondary market is more complicated because of the number of parties, as well as the kinds of transactions, involved. Investors place a variety of orders over differing time horizons with or without leverage for multiple securities in the secondary market. Incorporating all these variables for a mechanism like ABSA involves escrow arrangements with counter parties in a dynamic environment.The technical challenge may be considerable but not insurmountable. In this, the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) is on the right course in its effort to provide such a structure for investors. The Unified Payments Interface (UPI) allows money used for trading to be transferred directly to clearing corporations, which can then settle with brokers. This flushes out money idling with brokers. Lowering risk of abuse and containing the fallout in case of broker default. This also offers a pathway for direct settlement, bypassing the pool accounts of intermediaries, SEBI has thus, acted on its regulatory remit of protecting investors' cash as well as their securities.SEBI has offered relief to brokerages that stand to lose float income on account of up streaming client money to clearing corporations. Brokerages have been allowed to upstream clients' funds in the form of fixed deposit lien or mutual fund units. This should keep intermediation fees low while the market regulator nudges the system to clear excess funds from the broker channel. Higher upfront brokerage fees are an improvement over those subsidized by float income. Bettering systemic oversight. This could lead to concentration among brokerages discount players lose their advantage.The money used for trading is allowed to be transferred directly to clearing corporation, through:
  • A.Escrow Arrangement
  • B.Unified Payments Interface
  • C.E-banking
  • D.Credit cards
Correct Answer: Unified Payments Interface

The passage mentions that the Unified Payments Interface (UPI) allows money used for trading to be transferred directly to clearing corporations. Therefore, the correct answer is option B.

Question 98
Read the passage and choose the correct answer from the options given below:The proposed facility similar to the Applications Supported by Blocked Amount (ASBA) for secondary markets has elements to protect investors while increasing their potential earnings. The way it works now in the primary market is that money remains blocked in investor accounts, earning interest till issues of Initial Public Offerings (IPO) accept subscriptions. Replicating this for the secondary market is more complicated because of the number of parties, as well as the kinds of transactions, involved. Investors place a variety of orders over differing time horizons with or without leverage for multiple securities in the secondary market. Incorporating all these variables for a mechanism like ABSA involves escrow arrangements with counter parties in a dynamic environment.The technical challenge may be considerable but not insurmountable. In this, the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) is on the right course in its effort to provide such a structure for investors. The Unified Payments Interface (UPI) allows money used for trading to be transferred directly to clearing corporations, which can then settle with brokers. This flushes out money idling with brokers. Lowering risk of abuse and containing the fallout in case of broker default. This also offers a pathway for direct settlement, bypassing the pool accounts of intermediaries, SEBI has thus, acted on its regulatory remit of protecting investors' cash as well as their securities.SEBI has offered relief to brokerages that stand to lose float income on account of up streaming client money to clearing corporations. Brokerages have been allowed to upstream clients' funds in the form of fixed deposit lien or mutual fund units. This should keep intermediation fees low while the market regulator nudges the system to clear excess funds from the broker channel. Higher upfront brokerage fees are an improvement over those subsidized by float income. Bettering systemic oversight. This could lead to concentration among brokerages discount players lose their advantage.Which are reasons that make replication of ASBA for the secondary market complicated?(a) Kinds of transactions(b) Presence of large number of brokers(c) Applicability of SEBI guideline(d) Number of Parties(e) Differing time horizonChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.c, d and e only
  • B.a, b and c only
  • C.a and d only
  • D.b and c only
Correct Answer: a and d only

According to passage, the reasons that make replication of ASBA for the secondary market complicated are (i) the kinds of transactions (ii) and the number of parties. Therefore, correct answer is option C.

Question 99
Read the passage and choose the correct answer from the options given below:The proposed facility similar to the Applications Supported by Blocked Amount (ASBA) for secondary markets has elements to protect investors while increasing their potential earnings. The way it works now in the primary market is that money remains blocked in investor accounts, earning interest till issues of Initial Public Offerings (IPO) accept subscriptions. Replicating this for the secondary market is more complicated because of the number of parties, as well as the kinds of transactions, involved. Investors place a variety of orders over differing time horizons with or without leverage for multiple securities in the secondary market. Incorporating all these variables for a mechanism like ABSA involves escrow arrangements with counter parties in a dynamic environment.The technical challenge may be considerable but not insurmountable. In this, the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) is on the right course in its effort to provide such a structure for investors. The Unified Payments Interface (UPI) allows money used for trading to be transferred directly to clearing corporations, which can then settle with brokers. This flushes out money idling with brokers. Lowering risk of abuse and containing the fallout in case of broker default. This also offers a pathway for direct settlement, bypassing the pool accounts of intermediaries, SEBI has thus, acted on its regulatory remit of protecting investors' cash as well as their securities.SEBI has offered relief to brokerages that stand to lose float income on account of up streaming client money to clearing corporations. Brokerages have been allowed to upstream clients' funds in the form of fixed deposit lien or mutual fund units. This should keep intermediation fees low while the market regulator nudges the system to clear excess funds from the broker channel. Higher upfront brokerage fees are an improvement over those subsidized by float income. Bettering systemic oversight. This could lead to concentration among brokerages discount players lose their advantage.Given below are two statements: One is labelled as Assertion A and the other is labelled as Reason R.Assertion ‘A’:SEBI has offered relief to brokerages that stand to lose float income on account of up streaming client money to clearing corporations.Reason ‘R’:Brokerage have been allowed to upstream clients' fund in the form of fixed deposit lien or mutual fund units.In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
  • C.A is true but R is false
  • D.A is false but R is true
Correct Answer: Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A

Assertion A states that SEBI has offered relief to brokerages due to the potential loss of float income when they transfer client money to clearing corporations, which is true based on the passage.

Reason R states that brokerages have been allowed to upstream clients' funds in the form of fixed deposit lien or mutual fund units, which is also true based on the passage.

 

However, while both A and R are true, Reason R does not directly explain why SEBI offered relief to brokerages; it provides additional details about how brokerages can manage client funds but does not explain the rationale behind SEBI's decision.

Question 100
Read the passage and choose the correct answer from the options given below:The proposed facility similar to the Applications Supported by Blocked Amount (ASBA) for secondary markets has elements to protect investors while increasing their potential earnings. The way it works now in the primary market is that money remains blocked in investor accounts, earning interest till issues of Initial Public Offerings (IPO) accept subscriptions. Replicating this for the secondary market is more complicated because of the number of parties, as well as the kinds of transactions, involved. Investors place a variety of orders over differing time horizons with or without leverage for multiple securities in the secondary market. Incorporating all these variables for a mechanism like ABSA involves escrow arrangements with counter parties in a dynamic environment.The technical challenge may be considerable but not insurmountable. In this, the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) is on the right course in its effort to provide such a structure for investors. The Unified Payments Interface (UPI) allows money used for trading to be transferred directly to clearing corporations, which can then settle with brokers. This flushes out money idling with brokers. Lowering risk of abuse and containing the fallout in case of broker default. This also offers a pathway for direct settlement, bypassing the pool accounts of intermediaries,Sebihas thus, acted on its regulatory remit of protecting investors' cash as well as their securities.SEBI has offered relief to brokerages that stand to lose float income on account of up streaming client money to clearing corporations. Brokerages have been allowed to upstream clients' funds in the form of fixed deposit lien or mutual fund units. This should keep intermediation fees low while the market regulator nudges the system to clear excess funds from the broker channel. Higher upfront brokerage fees are an improvement over those subsidized by float income. Bettering systemic oversight. This could lead to concentration among brokerages discount players lose their advantage.The SEBI has acted on its regulatory remit of protecting investors cash and:
  • A.Securities
  • B.Dividend Income
  • C.Grievances of payment
  • D.Public Deposits
Correct Answer: Securities

According to passage, the SEBI has acted on its regulatory remit of protecting investors' cash and securities.

Quiz Attempt #118983

Total Questions: 100
Question 1
Which of the following is the right description of the “Duty Free Import Authorization (DFIA)” Scheme?
  • A.Duty free imports of inputs required for export production subject to certain export obligations, as stipulated in the foreign trade policy.
  • B.Exemption in respect of custom duty, additional duty, education cess and anti-dumping or safeguard duties for inputs used in exports.
  • C.Import of capital goods at concessional rate of duty subject to an appropriate export obligation accepted by the importer.
  • D.Grant of credit on post-export basis as specified percentage ofF.o.B.value of exports made in a freely convertible currency.
Correct Answer: Exemption in respect of custom duty, additional duty, education cess and anti-dumping or safeguard duties for inputs used in exports.

Under the DFIA scheme, duty free import of inputs, including fuel, oil, energy sources, and catalysts is allowed for production of export products subject to manufacturer exporters or merchant exporters tied up with the manufacturer for the import of inputs used in the manufacture of exports. It offers exemptions in respect of custom duty, additional duty, education cess, and anti-dumping or safeguard duties in force for inputs used in exports.

Question 2
An Indian company receiving investment from outside India for issuing shares/convertible debentures/preference shares under the FDI scheme should report the details of the inflow to the RBI. What is the time limit for reporting these details to RBI?
  • A.Within 10 days from the date of receipt.
  • B.Within 15 days from the date of receipt.
  • C.Within 30 days from the date of receipt.
  • D.Within 45 days from the date of receipt.
Correct Answer: Within 30 days from the date of receipt.

An Indian company receiving investment from outside India for issuing shares/convertible debentures/preference shares under the FDI scheme should report the details of the inflow to the RBI within 30 days from the date of receipt.

Question 3
Which one of the following theories of attitude change states that changes in opinions can result into an attitude change?
  • A.Balance theory
  • B.Cognitive consistency theory
  • C.Reinforcement theory
  • D.Cognitive dissonance theory
Correct Answer: Reinforcement theory

The correct answer is C – Reinforcement theory.

 

Reinforcement theory is a behaviourist theory that suggests that behaviours are shaped by the consequences that follow them. This theory proposes that behaviours that are followed by positive reinforcement (such as rewards) are more likely to be repeated, while behaviours that are followed by punishment or negative reinforcement are less likely to be repeated.

 

In the context of attitude change, reinforcement theory suggests that attitudes can be changed by reinforcing desirable attitudes and behaviours through rewards, and by punishing undesirable attitudes and behaviours. For example, a company might offer a reward to employees who exhibit positive attitudes towards customers, in the hope of shaping their attitudes and behaviours. This theory does not necessarily address the cognitive processes that may be involved in attitude change, such as cognitive dissonance or self-perception.

Question 4
According to Porter’s Diamond, which of the following isNOTa factor of national competitive advantage?
  • A.Relating and supporting industry
  • B.Firm strategy, structure and rivalry
  • C.Bargaining power of buyers
  • D.Demand conditions
Correct Answer: Bargaining power of buyers

Porter’s Diamond is a framework for analysing the competitive advantage of a nation. It consists of 4 interconnected factors that determine national competitive advantage:

(i) Factor conditions: the nation's position in factors of production such as skilled labour, natural resources, and infrastructure.

(ii) Demand conditions: the nature and size of the home market for goods and services.

(iii) Relating and supporting industries: the presence or absence of supplier and complementary industries that support and strengthen the main industry.

(iv) Firm strategy, structure, and rivalry: the conditions that determine how companies are created, organized, and managed, and the nature of domestic competition.

 

Bargaining power of buyers is not one of the factors of national competitive advantage identified by Porter's Diamond. The four factors mentioned above are considered the primary determinants of a nation's competitiveness in a specific industry

Question 5
X & Y are partners sharing profits and losses in the ratio of 3:2. They admit Z as a new partner with 1/5 share in the profits. Calculate the new profit-sharing ratio of the partners.
  • A.12:8:5
  • B.12:8:6
  • C.12:7:6
  • D.12:3:7
Correct Answer: 12:8:5

Let the total profit be 1

‘Z’ is admitted with Share = 15

Remaining share = 1 – 15 = 45

X’s share = 45 × 35 = 1225

Y’s share = 45 × 25 = 825

Z’s share = 15 or 525

Thus, the new ratio among X, Y and Z is. 12:8:5.

Question 6
At the break-even point, contribution is equal to:
  • A.Variable cost
  • B.Profit
  • C.Fixed cost
  • D.Sales
Correct Answer: Fixed cost

At the break-even point, contribution is equal to option (C) - Fixed cost.

 

The break-even point is the level of sales at which a company's total revenues equal its total expenses, resulting in zero profit or loss. The contribution margin is the difference between total sales revenue and total variable costs. At the break-even point, the contribution margin exactly covers the fixed costs, and there is no profit or loss.

Question 7
Which one of the following is NOT true?
  • A.Capital expenditure results in extra capacity.
  • B.Capital expenditure results in a benefit which will last for a long time.
  • C.Capital expenditure results in the acquisition of a permanent asset.
  • D.Heavy expenditure on advertisement campaigns in order to introduce a new product in the market.
Correct Answer: Heavy expenditure on advertisement campaigns in order to introduce a new product in the market.

Option D is the correct answer.

 

Capital expenditure refers to the expenditure incurred by a company on acquiring or improving its fixed assets, which are expected to benefit the company over a long period of time. Such expenditure results in the acquisition of a permanent asset, which adds to the company's capacity and can generate revenue over several years. Therefore, options A, B and C are true statements about capital expenditure.

 

Option D is incorrect because heavy expenditure on advertising campaigns is generally classified as revenue expenditure since it is incurred to promote sales and generate revenue in the current period. Advertising campaigns generally do not result in the acquisition of a permanent asset, nor do they add to the company's capacity. Therefore, option D is not true.

Question 8
As per the information given below, what is the correct material yield variance?Standard input = 100kgStandard yield = 90 kgStandard cost per kg of output =Rs. 20Actual input = 200 kgActual yield = 182 kgActual cost per kg of output =Rs. 19Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.Rs. 40 (Favourable)
  • B.Rs. 400 (Favourable)
  • C.Rs. 400 (Unfavourable)
  • D.Rs. 38 (Favourable)
Correct Answer: Rs. 40 (Favourable)

Standard Yield = 90100 ×  200 = 180

Material Yield Variance = (182-180) × 20 = 40 (F).

Question 9
When the negative income effect overwhelms the positive substitution effects so much that the demand curve is positively sloped, the commodity in consumption is described as:
  • A.Normal good
  • B.Inferior good
  • C.Giffengood
  • D.Luxury good
Correct Answer: Giffengood

When the negative income effect dominates the positive substitution effect, the demand curve of the commodity becomes positively sloped. This situation arises in the case of Giffen goods, which are inferior goods that have no close substitutes.

 

Giffen goods are goods for which demand increases as the price increases. This happens because the income effect of the price increase dominates the substitution effect. As the price of the Giffen good increases, the consumer's purchasing power decreases, causing them to switch to cheaper substitutes. However, since there are no close substitutes, the consumer has to continue to purchase the same quantity of the Giffen good at a higher price, resulting in a positively sloped demand curve.

 

Normal goods, on the other hand, have negatively sloped demand curves, indicating that as income increases, the demand for the good increases as well. Inferior goods, like Giffen goods, have negatively sloped demand curves, but they are not subject to the Giffen paradox. Luxury goods are goods that have a positive income elasticity of demand and are typically associated with higher levels of income.

Question 10
In the extreme case of perfect price discrimination, the entire consumer surplus in the market goes:
  • A.to consumers
  • B.to monopoly producer
  • C.as deadweight loss
  • D.to capital
Correct Answer: to monopoly producer

In the extreme case of perfect price discrimination, the entire consumer surplus in the market goes to option (B) - the monopoly producer.

 

Perfect price discrimination occurs when a monopolist charges each consumer the maximum price they are willing to pay for a unit of the good or service. In this situation, the producer captures the entire consumer surplus, as each consumer pays exactly what they are willing to pay.

 

Consumer surplus is the difference between what a consumer is willing to pay for a good or service and what they actually pay. In perfect price discrimination, the monopolist extracts the entire surplus, maximizing its profits at the expense of consumer welfare. Therefore, the correct answer is (B) to the monopoly producer.

Question 11
Read the passage below carefully and answer thequestionthat follow:Capital flows, exchange rates and the interest rates are causes of immediate concern to the national economies. Central banks of various countries have been using a variety of methods with the excessive capital inflows. Foreign portfolio investment has a direct and indirect impact on exchange rates, valuation of traded assets and yields of various government and corporate securities.RBI, in the post-pandemic scenario and the recent Russia-Ukraine war situation is working on multiple options to stabilize the exchange rates by protecting both the exporters and importers. One way which RBI adopts to maintain a desirable level of exchanges rates is to mop up nets foreign exchange assets from scheduled commercial banks in exchanges of domestic currencyassets. The liquidity flows are, in essence, inflationary. RBI has projected a comfortable GDP rate for the current fiscal and believes a reasonable level of CPI inflation as 5.3%.The retail inflation, according to the RBI governor, recently is likely to be 4.5% in 2023 fiscal. With this perspective, the repo rate and reverse repo rate remain at 4% and 3.35%, respectively, since May 22, 2020. A balancing act between economic growth and inflation is visible. Though the RBI rates are consistent, the burden on borrowers for the short-term and long­-term, is still unpredictable.Changes in foreign portfolio investments is directly related to:
  • A.Money demanded
  • B.Exchange rate
  • C.Prices
  • D.Circulation of money
Correct Answer: Exchange rate

Foreign portfolio investments refer to the investment in the financial assets of a country made by non-residents, such as stocks, bonds, and other securities. The changes in foreign portfolio investments can be directly related to various factors, including:

 

1. Economic conditions: Economic factors such as inflation, interest rates, and growth prospects can influence foreign investors' decisions to invest in a country's financial assets.

 

2. Political stability: Political stability, the rule of law, and government policies can also influence foreign investors' decisions to invest in a country.

 

3. Exchange rate: The exchange rate of a country's currency relative to other currencies can affect the attractiveness of the country's financial assets to foreign investors.

 

4. Market sentiment: The overall market sentiment, including investor confidence and risk appetite, can also influence foreign investors' decisions to invest in a country.

 

5. Global events: Global events such as geopolitical tensions, natural disasters, and pandemics can also affect foreign portfolio investments.

Question 12
A situation in which economic actors interacting with one another, each choose their best strategy, given the strategies that all the actors have chosen, is called:
  • A.Nash equilibrium
  • B.Prisoner’s dilemma
  • C.Dominant strategy
  • D.Predatory strategy
Correct Answer: Nash equilibrium

A Nash equilibrium is a concept in game theory that describes a situation in which each player in a game chooses the best strategy for themselves, given the strategies chosen by all other players. In other words, no player can improve their outcome by unilaterally changing their strategy, assuming all other players keep their strategies unchanged.

 

The concept is named after the Nobel Prize-winning economist John Nash, who introduced it in his 1950 paper “Equilibrium Points in N-Person Games.”

Question 13
In the Cobb-Douglas production function, Q = AKaLb, where ‘a’ and ‘b’ are output elasticities of capital and labour, respectively. If a + b > 1, the underlying return to scale will be:
  • A.increasing
  • B.decreasing
  • C.constant
  • D.linear
Correct Answer: increasing

In 1928, Cobb and Douglas introduced a famous two-factor production function, called Cobb-Douglas production function, in order to describe the distribution of the national income by help of production functions.

Q = AKαLβ

where:

Q = Output, A= Efficiency, K= Capital, L= Labour

parameters α and β represent the elasticity co-efficient of output for inputs K and L, respectively.

 

Degree of return to scale

1. Constant Return to Scale →α + β = 1

2. Increasing Return to Scale →α+ β> 1

3. Decreasing Return to Scale →α + β< 1

Question 14
Which one of the following institutions isNOTa part of the World Bank Group?
  • A.International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD)
  • B.International Development Association (IDA)
  • C.Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA)
  • D.The Bank for International Settlements (BIS)
Correct Answer: The Bank for International Settlements (BIS)

World Bank is an international organization that serves as a bank for central banks. Its main purpose is to foster international monetary and financial cooperation and to serve as a forum for central banks and other financial authorities.

 

The World Bank Group, on the other hand, is a collection of five international organizations that work together to promote economic development and reduce poverty around the world. The 5 institutions that make up the World Bank Group are:

  • International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD)
  • International Development Association (IDA)
  • International Finance Corporation (IFC)
  • Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA)
  • International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID)
Question 15
According to the traditional approach, what is the effect of increase in degree of leverage on the valuation of a firm?
  • A.Increases
  • B.Decreases
  • C.Remains unaffected
  • D.Increases first and then decreases
Correct Answer: Increases first and then decreases

The traditional approach to capital structure assumes that there is an optimal mix of debt and equity that maximizes a firm's overall value. This optimal mix is determined by finding the level of debt that balances the tax benefits of debt with the costs of financial distress and bankruptcy.

 

When a firm increases its degree of leverage (i.e., the proportion of debt in its capital structure), several effects are observed. Initially, as the degree of leverage increases, the cost of capital decreases due to the tax benefits of debt. This results in an increase in the firm's value.

 

However, as the degree of leverage increases further, the costs of financial distress and bankruptcy become more significant, leading to an increase in the cost of capital. This, in turn, reduces the firm's overall value. In addition, high levels of debt can also lead to agency costs and conflicts of interest between shareholders and creditors, which can further reduce the firm's value.

 

Therefore, according to the traditional approach, the effect of an increase in the degree of leverage on the valuation of a firm is that it increases initially due to the tax benefits of debt, but then decreases as the costs of financial distress, bankruptcy, and other factors outweigh the benefits of debt. The optimal level of debt that maximizes the firm's overall value is the point at which the tax benefits of debt are balanced with the costs of financial distress and bankruptcy, and this point varies depending on the specific characteristics of the firm, its industry, and the broader economic environment.

Question 16
An economic enterprise requires 90,000 units of certain item annually. The cost per unit is ₹3. The cost per purchase order is ₹300 and the inventory carrying cost is ₹6 per unit per year. What is EOQ?
  • A.3000 units
  • B.1500 units
  • C.6000 units
  • D.4500 units
Correct Answer: 3000 units

Economic Order Quantity = 2 ×90000×3006

= 3000 units

Question 17
Dell Ltd. hasRs. 100 preference shares redeemable at a premium of 10% with 15 years maturity. The coupon rate is 12%, the flotation cost is 5% and the sale price isRs. 95. Calculate the cost of preference shares and select the correct option.
  • A.12%
  • B.12.67%
  • C.13%
  • D.13.33%
Correct Answer: 13.33%

Kp= Pd+  (MV-NP)NaaMV+NP2

where,

Kp = Cost of redeemable Preference Capital

Pd = Annual Preference Dividend

MV = Maturity value of preference shares

NP = Net proceeds of Preference shares

N = Number of years after which preference shares are redeemed

Kp= 12 +  (110-90)15a100+902 = 13.33%

Question 18
Which of the following isNOTa characteristic ofNormal Distribution?
  • A.The mean of the normal distribution may be negative or positive.
  • B.For any normal random variable χ, P (χ ≤ μ) = P (χ ≥ μ) = 0.50
  • C.For every pair of values μ and σ, the curve of the distribution is bell-shaped and symmetric.
  • D.The kurtosis of the distribution is always less than 3.
Correct Answer: The kurtosis of the distribution is always less than 3.

The kurtosis of the distribution is always equal to 3. Hence option D is incorrect.

Question 19
For a Poisson distribution ρ(χ) =e-5(-5)22!the mean value is:
  • A.2
  • B.5
  • C.10
  • D.25
Correct Answer: 5

Equation for Poisson Distribution is given below:

Probability of x occurrences in an interval: P (x) = e-µ. μxX!

Range of X = 0, 1, 2, 3,……..∞

Expected Value or Mean, µ = λ

Variance = λ

Standard Deviation:  σ =  λ

The mean value is µ = 5.

Question 20
Which of the following is used to assess the relationship between two ordinal variables?
  • A.Spearman’s rho
  • B.Phi
  • C.Cramer’s V
  • D.Chi-square
Correct Answer: Spearman’s rho

Spearman’s rho is a non-parametric statistical measure used to assess the strength and direction of the relationship between two ordinal variables. It measures the degree of association between the two variables based on the ranks of their values rather than their actual values. The Spearman's rho coefficient ranges from -1 to +1, where -1 indicates a perfect negative correlation, +1 indicates a perfect positive correlation, and 0 indicates no correlation between the 2 variables.

 

Phi and Cramer’s V are statistical measures used to assess the relationship between two nominal variables. Phi is used to measure the degree of association between two dichotomous variables, while Cramer's V is used to measure the degree of association between two nominal variables with more than two categories.

 

Chi-square test is a statistical measure used to determine whether there is a significant association between two categorical variables. It assesses whether the observed frequency distribution of the data differs significantly from the expected frequency distribution under the assumption of no association between the variables. However, it does not provide information on the strength or direction of the relationship between the variables.

Question 21
A “Spurious” relationship between two variables is expressed as:
  • A.An apparent relationship that is so curious that it demands further attention.
  • B.A relationship that appears to be true because each variable is related to a third one.
  • C.One that is so ridiculously illogical that it cannot be possibly true.
  • D.One that produces a perfect negative correlation on a scatter diagram.
Correct Answer: A relationship that appears to be true because each variable is related to a third one.

A spurious relationship is a statistical relationship between two variables that appears to be true but is actually the result of a third variable that is related to both. In other words, a spurious relationship is a coincidence rather than a true causal relationship between the two variables.

 

For example, suppose there is a positive correlation between ice cream sales and the number of drownings in a city. One might be tempted to conclude that eating ice cream causes people to drown, but this is not the case. The spurious relationship is actually due to a third variable, temperature. Both ice cream sales and the number of drownings are related to temperature, with warmer temperatures leading to more ice cream sales and more people going swimming, resulting in more drownings.

 

In this case, the spurious relationship between ice cream sales and drowning disappears when temperature is taken into account. Temperature is the true causal variable that affects both ice cream sales and the number of drownings, and any relationship between ice cream sales and drowning is coincidental.

 

Spurious relationships can be avoided by carefully considering potential third variables that may be related to both of the variables being analysed. By controlling for these third variables, researchers can determine whether a true causal relationship exists between the two variables or if the relationship is merely spurious.

Question 22
Which one of the following motives characterizes dominant organizational climate of clubs?
  • A.Extension
  • B.Affiliation
  • C.Dependency
  • D.Achievement
Correct Answer: Affiliation

The dominant organizational climate of clubs is typically characterized by the motivation of affiliation. Clubs are social organizations that bring together individuals who share a common interest or purpose. The members of clubs often value the sense of belonging and social interaction that comes with being part of a group.

 

While other motives such as achievement, extension, and dependency may also be present in some clubs, the primary motivation is usually affiliation. Members join a club to socialize with others who share their interests, to participate in activities, and to enjoy the sense of belonging that comes from being part of a group. This motivation of affiliation is what drives the culture and activities of many clubs, from sports clubs to hobbyist groups to professional associations.

Question 23
Which one of the following is the description of Ego Regression Mechanism?
  • A.Returning to a previous stage of psyche development.
  • B.Avoiding unacceptable emotions by focusing on the intellectual aspects.
  • C.Taking out impulses on a less threatening target.
  • D.Pulling into the unconscious situation.
Correct Answer: Returning to a previous stage of psyche development.

Ego Regression Mechanism is a defence mechanism in psychoanalytic theory, which is used by individuals to cope with stress or anxiety. The mechanism involves returning to a previous stage of psychological development where they may have felt more secure and less threatened.

 

For example, an adult who is facing stress and anxiety at work may regress to a child-like state of dependence on others for support and comfort. In this state, they may feel more secure and less anxious.

 

Other defence mechanisms in psychoanalytic theory include:

B. Intellectualization - avoiding unacceptable emotions by focusing on the intellectual aspects.

C. Displacement - taking out impulses on a less threatening target.

D. Repression - pushing unacceptable thoughts or emotions into the unconscious.

Question 24
Which one of the following isNOTan advantage of organization structure by product in a manufacturing company?
  • A.Places attention and effort on product line.
  • B.Requires less persons with general managerial abilities.
  • C.Improves coordination of functional activities.
  • D.Permits growth and diversity of products.
Correct Answer: Requires less persons with general managerial abilities.

An organizational structure by product in a manufacturing company can lead to a more focused approach to product lines and promote growth and diversity of products.

Question 25
Which one of the following isNOTan assumption under the McGregor’s Theory Y?
  • A.The degree of commitment to objectives is in proportion to the size of the rewards associated with their achievement.
  • B.Under the conditions of modern industrial life, the intellectual potentialities of the average human being are only partially utilised.
  • C.External control and the threat of punishment are the only means for producing effort towards organizational objectives.
  • D.Average human beings learn, under proper conditions, not only to accept responsibility but also to seek it.
Correct Answer: External control and the threat of punishment are the only means for producing effort towards organizational objectives.

McGregor’s Theory Y is based on the idea that employees are intrinsically motivated to work towards organizational objectives and that they seek responsibility and self-fulfilment in their work.

 

The assumptions that are part of Theory Y are:

A. The degree of commitment to objectives is in proportion to the size of the rewards associated with their achievement.

B. Under the conditions of modern industrial life, the intellectual potentialities of the average human being are only partially utilised.

D. Average human beings learn, under proper conditions, not only to accept responsibility but also to seek it.

 

Therefore, option C is the assumption that is not part of McGregor's Theory Y.

Question 26
The minimum capital requirement for a lifeinsurance company in India is:
  • A.Rs. 300 crores
  • B.Rs. 200 crores
  • C.Rs. 500 crores
  • D.Rs. 100 crores
Correct Answer: Rs. 100 crores

The minimum capital requirement for a life insurance company in India is Rs. 100 crores.

Question 27
Universal banks that function as investment banks in India are regulated by:
  • A.SEBI
  • B.RBI
  • C.Ministry of Finance
  • D.IRDA
Correct Answer: SEBI

Universal banks that function as investment banks in India are regulated by SEBI.

Question 28
When the RBI desires to restrict expansion of credit, it:
  • A.increasesthe bank rate.
  • B.decreasesthe bank rate.
  • C.decreasesthe CRR for banks.
  • D.decreasesthe SLR for banks.
Correct Answer: increasesthe bank rate.

The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is responsible for regulating the money supply in the economy and maintaining price stability. One of the tools that the RBI uses to control the money supply is the bank rate.

 

The bank rate is the rate at which the RBI lends money to commercial banks. When the RBI increases the bank rate, it becomes more expensive for commercial banks to borrow money from the RBI, which reduces the amount of funds that banks have available to lend to their customers.

 

When the amount of funds available for lending by banks is reduced, it restricts the expansion of credit in the economy. This is because banks have less money to lend, which leads to higher interest rates and tighter lending standards.

 

Higher interest rates make borrowing more expensive for consumers and businesses, reducing their willingness and ability to take out loans. As a result, the demand for credit decreases, which slows down economic activity and restricts the expansion of credit in the economy.

Question 29
Which of the following refers to default-risk intermediation?
  • A.Borrowing short-term funds from savers and making long-term loans to borrowers.
  • B.Making loans to risky borrowers by attracting savings from the savers who are risk-averse.
  • C.Using information gathering skills of the intermediary.
  • D.Pooling small amounts of savings from individuals to give loans to others.
Correct Answer: Making loans to risky borrowers by attracting savings from the savers who are risk-averse.

Default-risk intermediation refers to the process by which financial intermediaries such as banks or other lending institutions make loans to risky borrowers while attracting savings from risk-averse savers. This process involves taking on credit risk in order to generate profits by charging higher interest rates to risky borrowers than the interest paid to savers.

 

In a default-risk intermediation process, the financial intermediaries act as a middleman between savers and borrowers, managing the risk of lending and investing on behalf of their clients. Savers deposit their funds with these intermediaries, who use these funds to make loans to borrowers who may be unable to obtain financing elsewhere due to their high risk profiles.

 

These borrowers are willing to pay a higher interest rate to compensate the intermediaries for the added risk of default. Meanwhile, the intermediaries use their expertise to evaluate the creditworthiness of the borrowers and take measures to mitigate the risk of default. They may require collateral or impose stricter loan covenants to reduce the risk of default and protect the interests of their savers.

 

By taking on the risk of default, intermediaries can generate profits from the interest rate spread between the rates paid to savers and the rates charged to borrowers. This intermediation process allows risk-averse savers to earn a return on their savings while providing financing to risky borrowers who may be excluded from the credit market.

 

However, default-risk intermediation can also lead to potential problems if the intermediaries do not properly assess the creditworthiness of the borrowers or manage the risk of default effectively. This can lead to defaults and losses for the intermediaries and their savers. Therefore, it is important for intermediaries to have proper risk management systems in place to ensure that they can continue to provide default-risk intermediation services in a sustainable and profitable manner.

Question 30
The knowledge and courtesy of employees and their ability to convey trust and confidence indicates which of the following?
  • A.Responsiveness
  • B.Assurance
  • C.Empathy
  • D.Reliability
Correct Answer: Assurance

The knowledge and courtesy of employees and their ability to convey trust and confidence typically indicate “Assurance”.

 

Assurance is one of the 5 dimensions of service quality in the SERVQUAL model, which is a widely used tool for measuring customer perceptions of service quality. Assurance refers to the ability of employees to convey trust, confidence, and competence to customers, which helps to build customer trust and confidence in the service provider.

Question 31
Which of the following isNOTtrue about rural markets?
  • A.Growth opportunities in rural markets are driving companies to them.
  • B.Information and communication technology are the drivers of change in rural markets.
  • C.Socio-economic changes are yet to happen to rural markets.
  • D.Rural consumers shop for grocery, apparels,consumerdurables ofagri-inputs in nearby urban shops.
Correct Answer: Socio-economic changes are yet to happen to rural markets.

In reality, rural markets are undergoing significant socio-economic changes due to factors such as increased literacy rates, rising incomes, and access to technology and communication. These changes have led to a shift in consumption patterns and a growing demand for branded products and services in rural areas.

Question 32
“Manufacturers of razors and cameras often price these products low and set high mark ups on razor blades and films.”As per the above statement, manufacturers of razors and cameras are using which one of the following?
  • A.Captive-product pricing
  • B.Two-part pricing
  • C.Product-bundling pricing
  • D.By-product pricing
Correct Answer: Captive-product pricing

The pricing strategy described in the statement is an example of captive-product pricing. Captive-product pricing is a strategy where the price of the main product is kept low to attract customers, but the price of complementary products or consumables (such as razor blades and films) is set high to make up for the low price of the main product. The idea is to create a "captive" market for the complementary products, where customers are more likely to continue buying the same brand of consumables instead of switching to a competitor.

Question 33
AVerticalMarketingSystem (VMS) combining successive stages of production and distribution under single ownership, is known as:
  • A.Corporate VMS.
  • B.Administered VMS.
  • C.Contractual VMS.
  • D.Conventional VMS.
Correct Answer: Corporate VMS.

A Vertical Marketing System (VMS) combining successive stages of production and distribution under single ownership is known as a Corporate VMS. Therefore, option A is the correct answer.

 

In a Corporate VMS, a single entity owns and operates the entire distribution channel, including manufacturing, wholesaling, and retailing. This type of system allows for greater control and coordination between the different stages of production and distribution, leading to greater efficiency and potentially higher profits. However, it also carries the risk of becoming too centralized, which can lead to inflexibility and difficulties in responding to changes in the market.

Question 34
The act of throwing on board cargo and other things from the ship to safeguard it from total loss in times of peril is called:
  • A.Jettisoning
  • B.Moral hazards
  • C.Consequential peril
  • D.Reverse indemnity
Correct Answer: Jettisoning

Jettisoning refers to the act of intentionally throwing overboard or off a ship, aircraft, or other vehicle, any cargo, goods, or equipment in order to lighten the load and prevent the vessel from sinking or crashing during times of peril, such as storms, rough seas, or other emergencies. The act of jettisoning is usually carried out as a last resort to save the vessel and the crew, and it is often a difficult and dangerous decision to make. Jettisoning may also be used as a deliberate strategy to reduce the weight of a vehicle in order to increase its performance or range.

Question 35
The right to ‘stoppage in transit’ exercised by an unpaid seller is to:
  • A.recover price
  • B.retain possession
  • C.regain possession
  • D.recover damages
Correct Answer: regain possession

The right to ‘stoppage in transit’ exercised by an unpaid seller is to regain possession. On the other hand, the essence of a right of lien is to retain possession.

Question 36
Which one among the following is the duty of the Central Assistant Public Information Officer or a State Assistant Public Information Officer?
  • A.To receive the applications for information or appeals under the RTI Act for forwarding the same forthwith to the CPIO/SPIO.
  • B.To receive the fee for the RTI applications.
  • C.To assist the CPIO/SPIO in furnishing the reply to the applicant.
  • D.To ensure that RTI applications are replied within the prescribed period.
Correct Answer: To receive the applications for information or appeals under the RTI Act for forwarding the same forthwith to the CPIO/SPIO.

The duty of the Central Assistant Public Information Officer or a State Assistant Public Information Officer is to receive the applications for information or appeals under the RTI Act for forwarding the same forthwith to the CPIO/SPIO

Question 37
The relationship between a bank and itscustomers is basically that of:
  • A.Debtor and Creditor
  • B.Trustee and Beneficiary
  • C.Principal and Agent
  • D.Drawer and Payee
Correct Answer: Trustee and Beneficiary

A bank's relationship with its customers can be compared to that of a trustee and beneficiary. The bank manages and invests the customers' funds, with a duty to act in their best interests. The bank must provide accurate account information, safeguard funds, and ensure customers have access to their money.

Question 38
Provisions of theVivadseVishwasAct, 2020 does not apply in respect of tax arrears relating to which one of the following?
  • A.anassessment year in respect of which prosecution has been instituted on or before the date of filing of declaration.
  • B.anyincome from agricultural land in India.
  • C.Section 10(3) dealing with tax deductions.
  • D.assessmentsunder Section 80 GI of the Act.
Correct Answer: anassessment year in respect of which prosecution has been instituted on or before the date of filing of declaration.

Where only notice for initiation of prosecution has been issued without prosecution being instituted, the assessee is eligible to file declaration under Vivad se Vishwas. However, where the prosecution has been instituted with respect to an assessment year, the assessee is not eligible to file declaration for that assessment year under Vivad se Vishwas, unless the prosecution is compounded before filing the declaration.

 

Therefore, correct answer is Option A.

Question 39
Under Section 8OTTB of the Income Tax Act, which amount of benefits is available to senior citizens on account of interest income from deposits with banks or post-office or cooperative banks?
  • A.Rs. 50,000
  • B.Rs. 1,00,000
  • C.Rs. 75,000
  • D.Rs. 1,50,000
Correct Answer: Rs. 50,000

Section 80TTB – in respect of interest on deposits in case of senior citizens

 

The deduction under this section is available from AY 2019-20 with respect to interest on deposit in saving/fixed account of a senior citizen (at least 60 years of age) with a banking company, a post office, co-operative society engaged in banking business, etc. (subject to certain conditions). The deduction is available up to 100% of amount of such income subject to maximum of Rs. 50,000.

Question 40
Provisional Input Tax Credit can be utilised against:
  • A.Any tax liability
  • B.Self-assessed tax liability
  • C.Differential income tax gains
  • D.Fine
Correct Answer: Self-assessed tax liability

Provisional Input Tax Credit can be utilized against self-assessed tax liability.

 

Provisional Input Tax Credit (ITC) is the credit that is made available to taxpayers for the tax paid on their purchases of goods and services, which can be utilized to set off their tax liability. It is called "provisional" because it is based on the taxpayer's own assessment of their tax liability, which may be subject to adjustment by the tax authorities at a later stage.

 

As per the GST (Goods and Services Tax) law in India, provisional ITC can be utilized by a taxpayer against their self-assessed tax liability, which means the tax liability that is declared by the taxpayer in their monthly/quarterly GST returns.

 

However, the provisional ITC cannot be utilized against any other type of tax liability, such as income tax gains or fines. It can only be utilized to set off the tax liability under the GST law.

Question 41
Penalty for late filing of the Income Tax Return for individuals under the Income Tax Act, 1961 is up to a maximum of amount of:
  • A.Rs10,000
  • B.Rs25,00,000
  • C.10% of Gross Total Income
  • D.2% of Tax liability
Correct Answer: Rs10,000

The assessee shall be liable for late filing fee u/s 234F i.e., Rs. 5,000 (if the return is furnished after the due date but on or before 31st December of the AY) or Rs. 10,000 (if the return is furnished after 31st December of the AY).

Question 42
Revenue expenditure of the Central government includes:A Debt relief to farmers.B. Subsidy for fertilizers.C. Grants to states.D. Central plan allocations for rural development.E. Central plan allocation for irrigation and flood control.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and E only
  • B.A, C and D only
  • C.C, D and E only
  • D.A, B and C only
Correct Answer: A, B and C only

Revenue expenditure is the expenditure incurred by the government on day-to-day expenses such as salaries, pensions, subsidies, and grants. The options given in the question are:

 

A. Debt relief to farmers – This is a revenue expenditure as it involves the transfer of funds to farmers to provide relief from their debts.

 

B. Subsidy for fertilizers – This is a revenue expenditure as it involves the transfer of funds to farmers to provide a subsidy for fertilizers.

 

C. Grants to states – This is a revenue expenditure as it involves the transfer of funds from the central government to the state governments.

 

D. Central plan allocations for rural development – This is a capital expenditure as it involves the creation of assets such as infrastructure for rural development.

 

E. Central plan allocation for irrigation and flood control – This is a capital expenditure as it involves the creation of assets such as irrigation systems and flood control infrastructure.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is Option D – A, B, and C only as options A, B, and C are revenue expenditures.

Question 43
Exchange depreciation rate of one currency in relation to another currency is, approximately, equal to their:A. Inflation rate differentialB. Interest rate differentialC. Growth rate differentialD. Fiscal deficit differentialE. Forex reserve differentialChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.C, D and E only
  • C.A and B only
  • D.D and E only
Correct Answer: A and B only

The exchange rate between two currencies is the price at which one currency can be exchanged for another currency. This rate is determined by various economic factors such as inflation, interest rates, trade balance, and political stability.

 

In general, the exchange rate between two currencies is influenced by their inflation and interest rate differentials. The relationship between exchange rate and inflation rate differential and interest rate differential is explained below:

 

(i) Inflation rate differential:

The inflation rate differential is the difference between the inflation rates of two countries. A higher inflation rate in one country than another can lead to a decrease in the value of its currency relative to the other country's currency. This is because a higher inflation rate erodes the purchasing power of the currency and makes it less valuable compared to the other currency. Therefore, the exchange rate may depreciate to adjust for this inflation rate differential.

 

(ii) Interest rate differential:

The interest rate differential is the difference between the interest rates of two countries. Higher interest rates in one country than another can lead to an increase in demand for its currency as investors seek higher returns. This increased demand for the currency can lead to an appreciation of its exchange rate relative to the other country's currency. Similarly, lower interest rates in one country than another can lead to a decrease in demand for its currency and cause its exchange rate to depreciate.

Question 44
Which of the following activities are included under investing activities in the Cash Flow Statement?a. Cash receipts from disposal of fixed assets (including intangible).b. Cash advances and loans made to third parties (other than advances and loans made by a financial enterprise).c. Cash receipts from repayment of advances and loans made to third parties (other than advances and loans of a financial enterprise).d. Cash repayments of amount borrowed.e. Cash payments to suppliers for goods and services.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a, b and c only
  • B.c, d and e only
  • C.c and d only
  • D.a, c and d only
Correct Answer: a, b and c only

As per AS-3, investing activities are the acquisition and disposal of long-term assets and other investments not included in cash equivalents. Investing activities relate to purchase and sale of long-term assets or fixed assets such as machinery, furniture, land and building, etc. Transactions related to long-term investment are also investing activities.

 

Cash Outflows from investing activities

  • Cash payments to acquire fixed assets including intangibles and capitalised research and development.
  • Cash payments to acquire shares, warrants or debt instruments of other enterprises other than the instruments those held for trading purposes.
  • Cash advances and loans made to third party (other than advances and loans made by a financial enterprise wherein it is operating activities).

 

Cash Inflows from Investing Activities

  • Cash receipt from disposal of fixed assets including intangibles.
  • Cash receipt from the repayment of advances or loans made to third parties (except in case of financial enterprise).
  • Cash receipt from disposal of shares, warrants or debt instruments of other enterprises except those held for trading purposes.
  • Interest received in cash from loans and advances.
  • Dividend received from investments in other enterprises.

 

Cash repayments of amount borrowed is a financing activity.

 

Cash payments to suppliers for goods and services is an operating activity.

Question 45
Identify cost drivers used in Activity Based Costing from the following:A. VolumeB. TransactionC. IntensityD. CurrencyE. DurationChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.C, D and E only
  • C.A, C and D only
  • D.B, C and E only
Correct Answer: B, C and E only

The correct cost drivers used in Activity Based Costing (ABC) from the given options are: B. Transaction, C. Intensity and E. Duration

 

Activity-Based Costing (ABC) is a cost accounting methodology that assigns costs to products and services based on their actual usage of resources. ABC uses cost drivers to allocate indirect costs to products or services based on their consumption of resources. The cost drivers are chosen based on the activity being performed and the resources consumed during that activity.

 

The cost drivers used in ABC should have a cause-and-effect relationship with the cost being allocated. The correct options from the given list are:

 

B. Transaction - This cost driver is used to allocate costs based on the number of transactions performed, such as the number of orders processed, invoices issued, or customer service requests handled.

 

C. Intensity - This cost driver is used to allocate costs based on the intensity or complexity of the activity being performed, such as the number of machine setups required, the number of engineering changes made, or the complexity of a product design.

 

E. Duration - This cost driver is used to allocate costs based on the time required to perform an activity, such as the amount of time spent on machine maintenance, the time spent on customer service calls, or the time spent on product development.

 

A. Volume and D. Currency are not commonly used as cost drivers in ABC as they do not have a direct cause-and-effect relationship with the consumption of resources during an activity.

Question 46
Increasing returns to scale arise because as the scale of operation increases it causes:A. more division of labour and specialisation.B. productive utilisation of machineryC. lower procurement and logistic costs.D. more difficulties in managing firm effectively.E. more economies in advertising.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.C, D and E only
  • C.A B, C and D only
  • D.A B, C and E only
Correct Answer: A B, C and E only

Increasing returns to scale refer to the situation where a proportionate increase in the scale of production results in a more than proportionate increase in output. This can occur due to various factors, such as increased specialization, better utilization of resources, and lower per unit costs.

The options given in the question are:

 

A. More division of labour and specialization - This can lead to increased efficiency and productivity, as workers become more skilled and specialized in their tasks.

 

B. Productive utilization of machinery - This refers to the ability to use machinery and other equipment more efficiently as production volumes increase, resulting in lower costs per unit of output.

 

C. Lower procurement and logistic costs - This refers to the ability to take advantage of economies of scale in purchasing and transporting raw materials and finished products, resulting in lower costs per unit of output.

 

D. More difficulties in managing firm effectively - This is not a factor that leads to increasing returns to scale. In fact, as the scale of operation increases, it can become more challenging to manage the firm effectively due to increased complexity and coordination issues.

 

E. More economies in advertising - This refers to the ability to take advantage of economies of scale in advertising and marketing activities, resulting in lower costs per unit of output.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is option D- A, B, C, and E only as options A, B, C, and E are the factors that contribute to increasing returns to scale.

Question 47
Consumer rationality implies which of the following assumptions?A. Non-satiety of needsB. Transitivity of preferencesC. Cardinal measurementD. Selfish economic motiveE. Ordinal measurementChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and B only
  • B.C and D only
  • C.A,C and E only
  • D.A, B and D only
Correct Answer: A, B and D only

Consumer rationality refers to the assumption that consumers make decisions that maximize their utility or satisfaction given their budget constraints. This assumption is central to consumer theory in economics.

 

The options given in the question are:

 

A. Non-satiety of needs - This assumption means that consumers have infinite wants and desires that can never be fully satisfied, and therefore always seek to increase their satisfaction.

 

B. Transitivity of preferences - This assumption means that if a consumer prefers A to B and B to C, then they must also prefer A to C. In other words, preferences are consistent and transitive.

 

C. Cardinal measurement - This assumption means that a consumer's level of satisfaction can be measured numerically. However, this assumption is not necessary for consumer rationality, as ordinal measurement (where preferences are ranked but not assigned numerical values) is sufficient for analysing consumer behaviour. This assumption is not required for consumer rationality.

 

D. Selfish economic motive - This assumption means that consumers act in their own self-interest when making economic decisions. This assumption is consistent with consumer rationality, as consumers are assumed to make decisions that maximize their own utility or satisfaction.

 

E. Ordinal measurement - This assumption means that a consumer's preferences can be ranked in order of preference, but not assigned numerical values. This assumption is not required for consumer rationality.

Question 48
Which of the following relationships raise presumptions of undue influence?a. Parent and childb. Doctor and patientc. Husband and wifed.Fianceandfianceee. Creditor and debtorChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a, b and c only
  • B.a, b and d only
  • C.a, b and e only
  • D.b, c and d only
Correct Answer: a, b and d only

As per Indian Contract Act 1872, certain relationships raise presumptions of undue influence, which means that there is a possibility that one party may use its position of power or authority to unfairly influence the other party in the contract. These relationships are considered to be inherently unequal or fiduciary in nature.

 

The relationships that raise presumptions of undue influence under the Indian Contract Act 1872 are:

(i) Parent and child

(ii) Doctor and patient

(iii) Fiance and fiancee

 

Therefore, the correct answer is option B. It is important to note that although the relationship between husband and wife is inherently fiduciary, it does not raise a presumption of undue influence under the Indian Contract Act 1872.

 

If a presumption of undue influence is raised, the burden of proof shifts to the party in the dominant position to prove that the contract was entered into freely and voluntarily by the other party, without any undue influence.

Question 49
The Internal Rate of Return (IRR) method offer which of the following advantages?A. It recognises the time value of money.B. It is consistent with the shareholders’profit-maximization objective also.C. It considers all cash flows occurring over the entire life of the project.D. It generally gives the same acceptance rule as the NPV method.E. It considers all positive NPV over the entire life of the project.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and E only
  • C.A, B, C and D only
  • D.A, D and E only
Correct Answer: A, B, C and D only

The Internal Rate of Return (IRR) method is a capital budgeting technique used to evaluate the profitability of investment projects. It is calculated as the discount rate at which the Net Present Value (NPV) of a project's cash flows equals zero. The advantages of the IRR method are:

 

A. It recognizes the time value of money - The IRR method considers the time value of money by discounting future cash flows to their present value, which helps to make more informed investment decisions.

 

B. It is consistent with the shareholders' profit-maximization objective - The IRR method is consistent with the objective of profit maximization, as it evaluates the project's profitability in terms of the expected return on investment.

 

C. It considers all cash flows occurring over the entire life of the project - The IRR method considers all cash flows over the life of the project, including both inflows and outflows, which helps to provide a comprehensive view of the project's profitability.

 

D. It generally gives the same acceptance rule as the NPV method - The IRR method generally gives the same acceptance rule as the NPV method, which is to accept projects with positive NPV or IRR values that exceed the required rate of return.

 

E. It considers all positive NPV over the entire life of the project - This statement is not entirely accurate as the IRR method considers all cash flows (both positive and negative) over the entire life of the project, not just positive NPV.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is Option C - A, B, C, and D only, as options A, B, C, and D, are the advantages of the IRR method.

Question 50
Which of the following are the off-balance sheet source(s) of finance?A. SecuritisationB. FactoringC. ForfaitingD. Operational leaseE. Credit ratingChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and E only
  • B.B, C and E only
  • C.A, B and C only
  • D.A, B, C and D only
Correct Answer: A, B, C and D only

Off-balance sheet sources of finance refer to financing activities that are not reported on a company’s balance sheet but are disclosed in its notes to financial statements or footnotes. The following are off-balance sheet sources of finance:

 

A. Securitisation - This refers to the process of pooling financial assets (such as loans, mortgages, or receivables) and issuing securities backed by those assets. The securities are then sold to investors, providing funds to the issuer without increasing its debt on the balance sheet.

 

B. Factoring - This refers to the process of selling accounts receivable (i.e., outstanding invoices) to a third-party (a factor) at a discount in exchange for immediate cash. Factoring allows companies to improve their cash flow without increasing their debt on the balance sheet.

 

C. Forfaiting - This refers to the process of selling long-term receivables (such as those arising from export transactions) to a forfaiter at a discount in exchange for immediate cash. Forfaiting allows companies to finance their export transactions without increasing their debt on the balance sheet.

 

D. Operational lease - This refers to the leasing of assets (such as equipment or machinery) for a period of time, where the lease payments are treated as operating expenses and do not appear on the balance sheet as debt.

 

E. Credit rating - This is not an off-balance sheet source of finance, as it refers to an assessment of a company's creditworthiness by a credit rating agency.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is Option D - A, B, C, and D only, as options A, B, C, and D are off-balance sheet sources of finance.

Question 51
Which of the following factors influence portfolio beta?A. Portfolio sizeB. Investment longevityC. Trading volumeD. Return interval (weekly vs. monthly)E. Portfolio leverageChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.D and E only
  • D.A, B, C and D only
Correct Answer: A, B, C and D only

Portfolio beta is a measure of a portfolio's systematic risk, which is the risk that cannot be diversified away. It is influenced by several factors, including:

A. Portfolio size - Larger portfolios are generally more diversified and have lower beta.

 

B. Investment longevity - Longer-term investments tend to have lower beta, as they are less influenced by short-term market fluctuations.

 

C. Trading volume - Higher trading volumes are generally associated with higher beta, as more actively traded securities are more sensitive to market movements.

 

D. Return interval (weekly vs. monthly) - The frequency of returns may affect the accuracy of beta estimation, with more frequent returns generally providing more accurate estimates. Shorter return intervals may increase the noise or volatility in the data, leading to less accurate beta estimates.

 

E. Portfolio leverage - This factor may influence the portfolio's total risk but does not directly affect its beta.

Question 52
A contract of life insurance is a/an:a. Indemnityb. Wagering agreementc. Contingent agreementd. Assurancee. GuaranteeChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a, c and e only
  • B.a and d only
  • C.b, c and e only
  • D.c and d only
Correct Answer: c and d only

A contract of life insurance is a contract of assurance and a contingent agreement.

 

A contract of life insurance is a contract of assurance because it provides financial protection to the policyholder or their beneficiaries in the event of a specified loss, such as death or disability. The insurer provides a predetermined sum of money to the designated beneficiary upon the occurrence of the specified event.

 

Additionally, a contract of life insurance is also a contingent agreement because it is dependent on the occurrence of a specific event, such as the death of the insured or the expiration of the policy term. The payout of the policy is contingent on the occurrence of the specified event. If the event does not occur, the insurer is not obligated to provide a payout.

Question 53
Which of the following statements are rightly expressed in relation to statistical testing?A. When the expected frequencies are too small, the value ofχ2will be overestimated and will result in too many rejections of the null-hypothesis.B. Mann-Whitney test assumes that population is normal.C.Kruskal-Wallis test is similar to one-way analysis of variance.D. The homogeneity of variance means that the test is concerned with the hypothesis that the identical means came from the same population.E. Student’s t-Distribution is by definition normal.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and D only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.A, C and E only
  • D.C and D only
Correct Answer: A, C and E only

The Mann-Whitney U test is a non-parametric test that does not assume normality of the population. In fact, it is specifically designed for comparing two independent samples that are not normally distributed.
